body.raw:
Blackriver Ramps faced a significant challenge with their annual Black Friday campaign.

Background

Despite the day’s potential for high sales volume, past efforts had not achieved the desired impact in terms of return on ad spend (ROAS) and overall engagement. The campaigns lacked the strategic differentiation and innovation needed to stand out in the highly competitive Black Friday environment.

In response to these challenges, Blackriver Ramps engaged Polything with a specific goal: to reinvigorate their Black Friday strategy and improve performance metrics.

This case study outlines our approach to restructuring their campaign, focusing on targeted strategies, audience engagement, and dynamic advertising solutions. It highlights the process from initial analysis and strategy development through to implementation and results evaluation.

Our collaboration aimed to not only enhance Blackriver Ramps’ Black Friday campaign results but also to set a new standard for their future digital marketing efforts. Here’s a comprehensive overview of the steps taken and the outcomes achieved, reflecting Polything’s commitment to delivering measurable success through tailored marketing strategies.

The Challenge

  • Past Performance: Previous Black Friday campaigns by Blackriver Ramps resulted in modest ROAS, failing to capitalize on the significant sales potential of the event.
  • Engagement Issues: The campaigns struggled to effectively engage their core demographic of 13-27-year-old skateboarding enthusiasts, leading to low conversion rates.
  • Market Differentiation: Amidst the saturated market of Black Friday deals, Blackriver Ramps’ offers were not sufficiently differentiated, blending into the vast array of promotions.

Strategic Solution

  • Prospecting – Identified and targeted potential new customers with interests aligned with skateboarding and fingerboarding culture.
  • Re-engagement – Reconnected with past visitors to reignite their interest using personalised messages.
  • Retargeting and Retention – Focused on individuals who had shown interest but did not purchase and rewarded loyal customers with exclusive deals.

Organic and Paid Synergies – Increased organic activity weeks before Black Friday to build anticipation. Utilised paid ads to amplify reach and engagement, ensuring a cohesive message across all platforms.

Dynamic Ad Utilisation – Implemented catalogue ads and dynamically generated ad formats, tailored based on the user’s past interactions, ensuring relevance and personalization.

Content Strategy – Diversified creative assets including videos, images, and time-specific messaging to keep the campaign fresh and engaging. Real-time Optimisation: Leveraged AI for on-the-fly adjustments based on live data to maximise campaign efficiency.

Implementation

  • Campaign Phases – Rolled out in defined stages, each phase targeted specific audience segments with tailored messaging and offers.
  • Content Deployment – Utilised a mix of media formats to maintain high engagement levels, ensuring content resonated with the target audience’s interests and needs.
  • Tech Integration – Applied the latest AI technology for campaign monitoring and adjustments, ensuring optimal performance throughout the campaign duration.

The Outcomes

  • ROAS – Achieved a significant increase, with a 14.55 return for every Euro spent.
  • Engagement – Higher frequency of meaningful interactions, indicating more effective reach to the target audience.
  • Cost Efficiency – Reduced overall campaign costs by 23% while improving outcomes.
  • Revenue Growth – Marked a 22% increase in revenue compared to previous years.

Segmented and Targeted Approach

Insights and Learnings

  • Strategic Flexibility – The importance of agility in strategy and real-time optimization was key to maximising campaign performance.
  • Audience Understanding – Deep insights into the target demographic and personalized engagement strategies proved crucial for conversion rate improvements.
  • Innovative Solutions – Leveraging technology and dynamic content personalisation significantly enhanced campaign effectiveness.
  • Real-time Optimisation: Leveraged AI for on-the-fly adjustments based on live data to maximise campaign efficiency.

Client Feedback

This is what BlackRiver had to say about the campaign:

“Partnering with Polything transformed our Black Friday campaign from just another sale to a major win. Their insight and innovation didn’t just elevate our tactics; they revolutionised our results. The team is more than a consultancy, they’re the strategic ally every ambitious brand needs.“

Denise Herman – CEO, Blackriver Ramps

Conclusion

This case study exemplifies Polything’s strategic acumen and execution excellence in digital marketing. The Blackriver Ramps Black Friday campaign showcases our ability to transform challenges into measurable success. For businesses looking to elevate their marketing outcomes, Polything offers bespoke strategies rooted in deep market insights and innovative practices.

Interested in elevating your marketing strategy? Visit our Services page to learn how we can drive your business towards its goals, or contact us directly for a tailored consultation. Let’s replicate this success story together.

Read More

body.raw:
Bluefort Case Study – A Strategic Marketing Overhaul for Enhanced

Background

Bluefort, the UK’s leading independent Security Solutions Partner, specialises in comprehensive cybersecurity solutions.

Faced with the challenge of enhancing its market presence and customer engagement, Bluefort recognised the need to refine its existing marketing strategies.

Objectives

The primary objective was to translate Bluefort’s Balanced Scorecard (BSC) outcomes into actionable and detailed marketing strategies, ensuring alignment with their ambitious growth and market expansion goals.

Bluefort enlisted Polything’s expertise to review and enhance its BSC outputs, focusing on the development of a robust marketing strategy that was aligned with contemporary market demands.

The Challenge

Bluefort’s Balanced Scorecard provided a broad strategic overview, which, while comprehensive, lacked the specificity required for effective marketing execution. The challenges were to:

  • Effectively Target and Engage Customers – Tailor marketing initiatives to resonate deeply with distinct customer segments.
  • Leverage Market Opportunities – Dynamically respond to emerging trends and opportunities in the cybersecurity landscape.
  • Measure Marketing Impact – Establish clear metrics and KPIs to link marketing efforts directly with strategic objectives.

Our Strategic Solution

Polything approached the challenge with a three-stage strategy designed to transform Bluefort’s marketing framework into a dynamic and impactful engine:

Stage 1: Foundation Setting

  • Balanced Scorecard Review – Ensured the BSC fully aligned with Bluefort’s business objectives and market realities.
  • Stakeholder Interviews – Provided insights into operational, strategic, and cultural facets crucial for tailoring the marketing approach.
  • Discovery Session & Customer Value Journey – Mapped out the customer journey to identify and optimise key engagement touchpoints.

Stage 2: Strategic Deepening

  • Strategic Recommendations Delivery – Implemented findings from the initial review to refine marketing strategies.
  • Further Strategic Scoping – Identified additional areas requiring strategic enhancement.
  • Value Proposition Evaluation – Assessed and refined Bluefort’s value propositions to ensure market resonance.

Stage 3: Strategic Execution

  • Implementation of Strategic Work – Applied the refined strategies to Bluefort’s marketing operations.
  • Test and Learn Programme Rollout – Initiated a cyclical programme to continuously refine strategies based on real-time feedback.
  • Forecasting and Resourcing Plan -Developed comprehensive plans to ensure the availability of necessary resources for future marketing needs.

Implementation

Polything’s implementation focused on meticulous planning and agile execution, ensuring each phase was seamlessly conducted to optimise Bluefort’s strategic marketing outcomes:

  • Strategy Refinement and Execution – Tailored marketing strategies were refined and implemented, ensuring they were robust and responsive to the dynamic market.
  • Continuous Learning and Adaptation – The test and learn programme facilitated ongoing adjustments and improvements in marketing tactics.

The Outcomes

The strategic overhaul led to significant enhancements in Bluefort’s marketing efficacy:

  • Marketing Strategy Statement -Clearly articulating the strategic marketing journey and future direction.
  • Enhanced Marketing Frameworks -Including a detailed strategic brand pyramid and comprehensive brand guidelines.
  • Operational Improvements – Greater alignment of marketing efforts with strategic objectives, improved target engagement, and better leverage of market opportunities.
  • Great product focus—One key takeaway from the work was that more focus needed to be placed on Evolve and that it needed to be developed into a standalone product.

Client Feedback

This is what Bluefort’s founder had to say about the engagement:

“Polything’s expertise in refining our Balanced Scorecard and translating it into actionable marketing strategies has been transformative. Their strategic insights have sharpened our campaigns and elevated our entire marketing approach.“

Dave Henderson – Sales & Marketing Director, Bluefort Security.

Conclusion

This case study exemplifies how strategic refinement can transform a company’s marketing approach and internal coherence, setting new standards in the industry. Bluefort’s journey with Polything highlights the importance of a meticulous, phased approach to strategic marketing planning and execution, proving that even established market leaders can achieve new heights of innovation and customer engagement.

Interested in elevating your marketing strategy? Visit our Services page to learn how we can drive your business towards its goals, or contact us directly for a tailored consultation. Let’s replicate this success story together.

Book a call

Client: Bluefort Security
Strategy: Chris
Production: In-House

seo.title: Bluefort Security – CRAFT Subscription
seo.description: Delve into how Polything transformed Bluefort s strategic marketing framework, leading to significant enhancements in market positioning and customer engagement

body.raw:
Bluefort Security – Craft Marketing Solutions Case Study

Enhancing Marketing Capabilities Through Craft Marketing Solutions

Background

Bluefort, a premier Security Solutions Partner in the UK, provides top-tier cybersecurity solutions.

With ambitions to significantly enhance its marketing effectiveness, Bluefort faced challenges in scaling its marketing operations effectively without incurring the overhead of additional full-time staff.

Objectives

The primary goal was to rapidly expand Bluefort’s marketing output to support a robust test-and-learn programme, aiming to refine market strategies and enhance brand consistency across all channels.

Bluefort engaged Polything and its Craft Marketing Solution through a bespoke subscription plan, designed to meet their specific needs for continuous, high-quality marketing output at a predictable cost.

The Marketing Challenge

Bluefort’s strategy required an accelerated production of diverse marketing assets and brand collateral. The challenges included:

  • Efficiency – Managing the production of marketing materials efficiently while ensuring high quality and strategic alignment.
  • Scalability – Expanding marketing production rapidly to keep pace with strategic growth initiatives without expanding internal teams.
  • Consistency – Maintaining brand consistency across an increasing array of marketing materials and platforms.

Craft Subscription in Action

Craft Marketing Solution addressed these needs with a subscription-based model tailored specifically for Bluefort, encompassing:

Initial Project Focus

  • Marketing Strategy Statement – To align all internal stakeholders with the refined marketing strategy.
  • Brand Guidelines Development – To ensure all marketing materials consistently reflect Bluefort’s brand identity.

Comprehensive Marketing Activation

  • Asset Creation – Development of corporate decks, sales materials, product datasheets, and more.
  • Brand Development – Creation of brand elements like logos, colour palettes, and brand patterns.

Implementation

We implemented a structured, phase-based approach to meet Bluefort’s marketing demands:

  • Phase 1 – Immediate Needs
    • Rapid development and rollout of essential marketing and sales collateral to support ongoing strategic initiatives.
  • Phase 2 – Brand Consistency
    • Systematic creation and implementation of brand guidelines to ensure consistency across all marketing outputs.
  • Phase 3 – Long-term Development
    • Ongoing development of strategic brand assets and marketing materials aligned with Bluefort’s evolving market strategies.

The Outcomes

The activation strategy led to significant improvements in Bluefort’s marketing capabilities:

Comprehensive Marketing Overhaul

  • A complete suite of marketing assets was developed, including corporate decks, sales materials, and brand collateral.

Enhanced Brand Consistency

  • Newly established brand guidelines ensured a cohesive brand identity across all platforms.

Efficient Asset Production

  • Craft Marketing Solution’s subscription model enabled efficient, cost-effective production of high-quality marketing materials.

Client Feedback

This is what Bluefort’s founder had to say about the engagement:

“Polything’s Craft Marketing Solution subscription has been a game-changer for Bluefort, enabling us to dynamically scale our marketing efforts and maintain brand consistency across all channels.

The quality and speed of delivery have exceeded our expectations, supporting our growth and helping us stay competitive in a tough market.“

Dave Henderson – Sales & Marketing Director, Bluefort Security.

Conclusion

This case study illustrates the effectiveness of Craft Marketing Solution’s subscription model in transforming Bluefort’s marketing operations.

The flexible, scalable service allowed Bluefort to enhance its marketing output and brand presence significantly, setting a new industry standard for marketing efficiency and consistency. This partnership demonstrates how tailored marketing solutions can facilitate rapid growth and strategic market adaptation.

Interested in elevating your marketing outputs? Visit our Services page to learn how we can drive your business towards its goals, or contact us directly for a tailored consultation. Let’s replicate this success story together.

Book a call

seo.title: WOLF – Case Study
seo.description: WOLF came to us wanting a strategy to scale their marketing in a core market which was overseas.

body.raw:
WOLF (The World’s Online Festival) – Case Study

WOLF came to us wanting a strategy to scale their marketing in a core market which was overseas.

Background

WOLF (The World’s Online Festival) is a social networking app focusing on live audio entertainment. The app is a 24/7 virtual world of social connection, communities and content creation where people can enjoy the same entertainment, fun and friendship they would experience, at a real-world festival.

The concept came from the founder, Martin Rosinski, and his own passion for real-life festivals. He loved the experience of discovering new talent, enjoying new entertainment, watching emerging artists perform while hanging out with friends and stepping away from normal life.

Based in the UK (London and Newcastle), WOLF’s primary market was Saudi Arabia.

Opportunity/Challenge

They had not actively marketed the app for years. The management team now saw an opportunity for growth. They did not have an in-house marketing team, as the previous team had left the business. However, they had a remote support team based in Jordan.

When we were first engaged, the company had just undergone a rebrand from Palringo to WOLF. Palringo had poor associations in-market because of issues with spam.

The brief was to create a strategy and scale marketing in an overseas market with a limited budget and insight into that market.

The Solution

We delivered strategy sessions with the Chief Growth Officer and the extended team. This included market sizing exercises, business modelling and customer journey mapping. The result was a fifty-point marketing programme delivered over the next 12-18 months to create a cut-through for the rebrand. After assessing resourcing, we formed a consensus that the in-house teams could not deliver the plan alone.

WOLF appointed Polything to deliver ongoing strategy, programme management on the project, campaign activation and creative production. We operated as an extension of the in-house team, managing other suppliers and projects, managing the programme and upskilling in-house teams. Also, part of the remit was also to develop the high-level rebrand pack and bring the brand alive across social, corporate site, websites and in-app.

The Scope

As part of the engagement, we provided training and coaching for WOLF’s in-house teams as well as developing SOPs and processes for them to deliver elements of the marketing programme.

Polything worked with the in-house team to develop clear segmentation, messaging and brand proposition based on user insights and delivered acquisition campaigns until the in-house team gained enough confidence to take over campaign management.

  • We developed an RFP for WOLF’s first corporate site, and selected appropriate vendors to work with. However, in the end, Polything designed and built their first site together with copy, visuals and video assets.
  • Polything was also responsible for campaign and cost management across the programme, as well as building LTV models and helping their data team create more robust reporting across the business.
  • We worked with various in-market consultants and agencies to get more market intelligence and develop strategies and tactics based on these insights.
  • Polything worked with in-house teams to create a plan to scale marketing beyond the KSA core market, initially to the GCC, then to the Lavant, and finally the rest of the Arabic Diaspora. This included a user forecasting model.
  • We delivered Brand development work across corporate, web, social and in-app channels.
  • Polything provided creative development services to assist WOLFs transition into a metaverse-focused application.
  • We worked with the Founder to translate the product roadmap into actionable creative production and marketing projects.
  • Polything also ran an RFP to appoint an in-market agency in Saudi Arabia, to double down on the progress that had been made and further develop messaging for the GCC.
  • We project-managed larger creative production jobs, including music videos and influencer marketing activity, as well as creating campaign lockups and supporting assets.

The Outcomes

WOLF acquired over 2 million new app users from its target market in the first two years since its brand relaunch.

This equated to a 65% increase in their daily active user number over the course of Polything’s engagement.

The first all-female talent competition delivered in the GCC, a watershed cultural moment for KSA.

Here’s the output of the engagement in numbers:

  • 1 marketing strategy and 50-point plan
  • 1 corporate website design and build
  • 1 marketing programme project managed
  • 1 user LTV model created
  • 2 RFP processes completed
  • 3 new regional markets activated
  • 4 quarterly activations planned and delivered
  • 94 creative and marketing projects delivered
  • 9.5GB of marketing assets created
  • 2,000,000 app downloads generated

Don’t take our word for it. Read WOLF’s full review on Clutch. The world’s leading ratings and reviews platform for IT, marketing, and business services companies.

Read More

body.raw:
![6 Benefits of Growth Marketing](https://polything.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2022/06/benefits-of-growth-marketing.jpg) ## 6 ways that growth marketing could help your business As a business owner, I am sure you're always looking for new ways to grow your company. You might be thinking about expanding into new markets, launching a new product, or need to increase profitability. But have you considered how [growth marketing](https://polything.co.uk/) examples could help you with these goals? There are many benefits to growth marketing for businesses. This article will explore six of the most important benefits of growth marketing. By understanding these benefits, you can see why growth marketing is so essential for businesses looking to achieve continued success.

What is growth marketing? Growth vs Marketing

Growth marketing is a customer-centric approach to business growth that focuses on identifying and exploiting new growth opportunities. By taking a >Growth hacking and growth marketing are two terms that are often used interchangeably, but there is a key difference between the two. Growth hacking is a more tactical approach to growth that focuses on using quick and dirty methods to achieve growth goals.

Growth marketing, on the other hand, is a more strategic and >By adopting a growth marketing methodology it will help your business grow in the following ways:

Uncover new market opportunities

Growth marketing is all about finding new opportunities for growth. By taking a >Growth marketing enables businesses to make more effective use of their budgets. By allocating budgets based on data, and experiments, companies can ensure that they are spending money on the most effective growth strategies. Growth marketing helps businesses generate higher-quality leads. By taking a strategic approach to lead generation, businesses can improve the quality of their leads and close more deals. This in turn improves retention and lifetime value.

Evolve your products and services in conjunction with your customer base

By taking [a strategic approach](https://polything.co.uk/approach/), one of the key benefits of growth marketing is that it creates [customer-centric products](https://www.strategyzer.com/blog/starting-with-the-customer) and organisations. This means that businesses can focus on their customers’ needs and wants, rather than just selling them products or services. By radically shifting this focus from product to consumers organisations can build better products, reach their consumers more efficiently, at the right times and build longer-term relationships with consumers that have greater value.

Strategy focused

Another key benefit of growth marketing is that it provides a focus on strategy, rather than tactics. Trust in the process is key to developing an effective growth marketing strategy. Understanding the iterative nature and small incremental improvements will ultimately result in big breakthroughs in understanding as well as direct. This means that businesses can start developing long-term plans and objectives, rather than obsessing over short-term tactical wins.

Cross-functional collaboration

Another benefit of growth marketing is that it enables businesses to collaborate more effectively across functions. This is because it recognises that no one department or individual can achieve growth on their own. Adopting an organisational North Star for the business creates clarity for everyone and provides context to make any decision within the business (e.g. If in accounts we'd do X does it have a positive or negative impact on Y='Our North Star').

Organisational alignment

Growth marketing also creates organisational alignment, which is essential for businesses that want to be successful. This is achieved by aligning the organisation’s goals, objectives, and strategies with its marketing efforts. Every department within the organisation will start to pull together to see each of its functions through the prism of how they can contribute to the North Star. Alignment of your whole business at a strategic level is a major benefit of growth marketing.

Data-informed decision making

An additional benefit of growth marketing is led by >A benefit of growth marketing is that hunches can be tested, at a much smaller scale, with a valid hypothesis that will return a result that can be validated before committing large amounts of time, effort, and money to ideas that may be driven by ego alone.

Increases profits

Finally, by its very nature, a benefit of growth marketing is that it is focused on increasing profits for businesses. This is achieved by identifying and exploiting new growth opportunities, creating a better product/market fit, as well as pursuing efficiencies in all areas of the business. When implemented correctly it can completely change the fortunes of an ailing business.

Conclusion

The benefits of growth marketing are essential for businesses that want to see continued success, particularly in markets that are constantly evolving and an environment where consumers' time is at a premium. By taking a strategic approach to lead generation, product development, and marketing, businesses can increase profits and build longer-term relationships with consumers.

Introduction

Today, the marketing landscape is constantly changing. With new technologies and social media platforms emerging every day, it’s difficult to keep up with everything that you need to do in order to market your company effectively. But there is a solution: agile marketing. Agile marketing focuses on delivering incremental value over time instead of trying to create the perfect plan upfront.

Many of the leading organisations have adopted agile including; NASA, Spotify and even the US Government. This article will walk readers through the various steps to create an agile marketing plan. It will outline the differences between a traditional waterfall plan and an agile plan as well as explain key concepts behind why it is better in today’s fast-paced marketing landscape.

1. What is agile marketing?

Agile marketing is a method of planning that uses incremental development. It focuses on delivering value over time instead of trying to create the perfect plan upfront. Agile helps marketers, product managers and businesses deliver quality work faster by breaking down large chunks of work into manageable pieces. This allows teams to meet deadlines more effectively while also allowing them to adapt to changes throughout the process.

2. Why use agile marketing?

Today, the marketing landscape is constantly changing. With new technologies and social media platforms emerging every day, it’s difficult to keep up with everything that you need to do in order to market your company effectively. But there is a solution: agile marketing. Agile helps marketers deliver quality work faster by breaking down large chunks of work into manageable.

What are the Advantages of Agile Marketing?

Agile marketing allows for flexibility and adaptability in developing a plan, taking into account that changes can happen quickly within today’s digital age. This type of planning takes place through short sprints which have specific goals to reach overtime, whereas traditional plans involve long-term budgets and timeframes.

Customers want a two-way dialogue with companies now more than ever before, which agile gives them the opportunity to do through personalised customer journeys. Agile marketing also reduces risks involved in planning as it allows businesses to quickly adapt to any changes within their industry or the behaviours of customers. This type of marketing is suitable for any business or industry because it is flexible and adaptable.

What are the Advantages of Agile Marketing?

There are no disadvantages to agile marketing, as long as you have a good understanding of how it works. It only requires an initial time investment in order to learn about new concepts before fully implementing them into your business. The key element is to be able to instil cultural change within your existing marketing team or build a new team that understands this methodology.

What are the steps to building an agile marketing plan?

– Understand the concept of agile

– Learn about its team structure and roles that are involved in it

– Communicate with your marketing department to build a new culture within the company based on this methodology

– Implement these steps into your business by breaking down tasks, creating sprints and focusing on delivering results.

3. The process of creating an agile marketing plan

The process of creating an agile marketing plan should break down into three different areas: the backlog, sprints and reporting. Regular retrospectives and daily standups are also important to check in with your team and make sure everyone is on the same page.

– First, you should figure out what needs to be done (the backlog), as well as prioritising those tasks

– Once completed, it’s time to create sprints and assign different parts of your plan into these sprints

– Once those steps are completed, it’s time to create sprints and assign different parts of your plan into these sprints

– You should also schedule a retrospective at the end of each sprint where you can discuss what went well and which areas need improvement. This is important in order to improve going forward

– Once all tasks have been completed within a project, it’s time to report on the results and see how you can improve for next time.

The three main steps in creating an agile marketing plan: breaking down large tasks into smaller, more manageable sprints; having a culture where people check in with each other daily and reporting back at the end of every project.

Backlog

A product owner must first develop a prioritised list of features that need to be developed in order for the final product to meet end-user expectations as well as provide value (the ‘backlog’). This list is often called the ‘backlog’ and serves as a reminder of what needs to be done, in priority order.

Sprints

Once you have determined your backlog items, develop an incremental list of work that will help get them completed (called sprints). At regular intervals (usually between one week and four weeks), take stock of where you’re at and plan where you want to go. This is a good time for product owners, developers and testers to meet together in order to validate that they are going down the right path with development as well as identify any obstacles which may be slowing them down or stopping them from achieving their goals.

Reporting

Marketing directors can then use the reports generated by the marketing team to evaluate their progress. You can continue to incrementally develop your product/service, building upon what you have already done, using an agile approach.

Daily Standup Meetings

Daily Standups are a great way to get everyone on the same page, no matter what they are working on. This allows them to communicate effectively and ensure that there is never any overlap or misunderstandings when it comes to their roles. Standups should only last between 15-20 minutes so that your team can quickly go through all of the necessary updates without wasting too.

Retrospectives

Retrospectives are crucial for agile teams because they allow them to reflect on what has happened in the past and then decide how best to move forward. This allows companies to identify any problems that may have occurred, regardless of whether it was something small or large so that everyone can work out where improvements need to be made before the next sprint.

4. How to write an agile marketing plan

An effective marketing strategy should start with a customer-centric view of all business functions and processes within the organisation so that everyone is working towards the same goal. This will ensure that they are all heading in the right direction and remain aligned, no matter where they sit within the organisation.

An agile marketing plan should be created after you have completed your business strategy or SWOT analysis and decided on a budget for your marketing activities as well as what resources you need to complete them.

The first step is to gather all your resources and decide who will be responsible for each activity, as well as how long it should take them to complete their task/activity. This information needs to go into the backlog so that you can identify what you need by when in order to achieve your goals on time. You may also want to outline the process for prioritising items in your backlog if there are multiple activities that need to be completed at the same time.

Thoroughly plan out each activity on an individual basis before looking at how they all tie together into one cohesive strategy. Consider what different types of goals you have, whether it’s improving brand awareness or increasing sales leads – and what your timelines are for each of these activities.

Once you have completed this step, take a look at how all the pieces fit together to create an overall marketing strategy that is integrated and coherent enough to meet your business goals. You should then start working on individual sprints (or mini strategies) in order to get things done more quickly so that you can get a better idea of whether it’s going to be successful or not.

An agile marketing plan is an effective way for companies to manage their digital presence and respond more quickly to customer demands by providing them with exactly what they want when they want it. It requires organisations to work together as one cohesive team so that everyone knows who is responsible for what. Agile marketing is a popular strategy because it allows companies to focus on their business more than ever before, without having to worry about whether they will have the resources available at any given time.

We have a team of highly experienced marketers who can help you implement an agile marketing plan that will stimulate your growth goals and increase customer satisfaction for years to come.

5. Tools to help you create your own plan

Kanban Boards

These are a great way to visualise your backlog and create a sense of transparency that everyone in the company can see exactly how things are going.

Jira – is a popular choice for agile teams because it makes collaboration easy due to its flexible configuration, user-friendly interface and powerful reporting features. It allows you to track bugs or add new tasks quickly so that you can get on with building your product.

Lean Canvas – is a helpful tool that enables teams to create their own Lean Startup business model canvas, which outlines the key components of an effective lean marketing strategy. It allows companies to visualise what they need in order to build something new and bring it to market successfully so that everyone knows exactly what they need to do and by when.

Trello – is a project management tool that is used to create Kanban boards or lists, depending on the type of agile methodology you want to implement. It allows teams to get organised and track their progress so they know exactly where they are at all times during the product development cycle.

Digital Asset Management Systems (DAM)

DAM is really important for agile marketing teams because they enable the entire team to have access to all of their assets at any time so that nothing gets left behind.

body.raw:
Content Marketing Basics: How to jump-start your journey and content practice

Content marketing is now an essential part of marketing strategy and is an industry which is still in growth. The global content marketing industry is estimated to be worth $407 billion in 2022 according to Absolute Reports, so there is no better time to start your content marketing adventure.

In the following article, we will explore why content marketing is important and how to get started with basic content marketing:

  1. Content Marketing Basics: How to jump-start your journey and content practice
  2. What is content marketing and why is it important?
  3. What are the basic content marketing principles?
    1. Research and know your audience
    2. Build a strategy
    3. Align your marketing channels to the ones your audience use
    4. Create a human tone of voice for your brand
    5. Be Consistent
  4. How to create high-quality content
  5. How to start marketing content
    1. Email marketing
    2. Social media
  6. Measuring success
    1. Website traffic
    2. Social Media Engagement
    3. Lead Generation
    4. Conversions (Sales)
  7. Conclusion
  8. Content Marketing FAQs

What is content marketing and why is it important?

Wikipedia defines content marketing as “a form of marketing focused on creating, publishing, and distributing content for a targeted audience online.”

However, this excludes one of the main precepts of content marketing. The tent is that by creating valuable, credible and relevant content consistently, will result in our target audience doing business with us and will engender loyalty to our brand.

Since the pandemic, there has been a huge uptick in the number of brands utilising content marketing to reach their customers, so this space is growing but is becoming even more competitive. There are types of content marketing, but there are now more than 1 billion blogs in the world which means that there is a blog for every 7.5 people in the world (source: Neil Patel).

This is important because it is no longer easy to create a simple blog and get a load of free traffic from Google Search. Your approach has to be more sophisticated and aligned with your target audience. But don’t worry, read on, and we will show you the basics of content marketing that will bring results.

What are the basic content marketing principles?

If you want to be successful with content marketing, there are some basic principles that you need to follow. These are:

Research and know your audience

Take the time to research your audience and develop a better understanding of what they’re looking for, what they need help with, and how you can add value to their lives. When you know your audience well, you can create content that speaks directly to their needs and pain points and does so in language that is helpful and credible.

Build a strategy

Before embarking on a content marketing programme it is critical to understand how and why you are undertaking this. Maybe your revenue is declining or you are launching a new product, in each of these examples your strategy will be wildly different depending on your business goals. If you need help defining a strategy we have content marketing services that can help.

Align your marketing channels to the ones your audience use

A TV executive once said to me “Content is King, but Distribution is King Kong”. The best content in the world is useless if your audience never sees it. People have become used to content finding them, rather than them having to find the right content.

Therefore, you must ensure that you align your content with the marketing channels your audience uses most. This means understanding what platforms they use (e.g., social media, search, email marketing, etc.), as well as the formats that they prefer to consume (e.g., articles, videos, etc.).

Create a human tone of voice for your brand

This is one of the most overlooked but crucial areas of content marketing, as our content needs to have a human voice that is relatable and trustworthy. This is relatively easy to create if you have brand pillars or a strategic brand triangle. if not it might be a good idea to work out what your brand or business stands for and build a brand personality.

Either way to build an editorial tone of voice it is important to consider what language you will use, and more importantly, what language you won’t use as well as what topics and conversations you will engage with. To formalise this it is quite often useful to create a content playbook.

Be Consistent

One of the main principles of content marketing is to be consistent with your messaging, frequency and quality. This can be challenging if you are a small team or business, but there are ways to make this easier. Perhaps you can build a bank of evergreen content that can be used as a resource when things get busy, or you might want to consider using a content calendar to help plan and organise your content in advance.

Also, consider starting with a very low frequency, and building the volume over time once you understand what types and topics of content work best for your audience.

Whatever approach you take, the most important thing is to be consistent with your content marketing, as this is what will help you gain the trust of your audience and keep them coming back for more. Sign up here to get our free content marketing pdf.

How to create high-quality content

Now we have covered the why who and how of content marketing, it is time to start creating content. This is probably the most important aspect of content marketing. Your content needs to be valuable and relevant, so you might like to check out what makes a good blog.

To ensure that it is, refer back to your research and make sure that each piece is tackling a problem or pain your audience has or is fulfilling a need for them to achieve something. An example might be to create a tool that simplifies a complex task (yes this is content), and it might have a better value long-term than just publishing an article on the subject.

To do this, refer back to your research and gain consensus within your business on the biggest pains your customers have. Rank these pains in order of importance. This is your initial list of content ideas.

Once ranked you can then have an ideation session to work out what content will be most relevant and useful for each pain. From this process, a natural path should become clear in terms of the format, structure and channel for the piece of content.

You maybe be able to produce content in-house with your existing team, or you may need to hire an agency or freelancers to help you with writing, design, and video production. There are many ways to resource this, so don’t be afraid to ask for help. Also, refer back to your strategy to see what makes sense and is viable for your business.

Finally here are 8 content examples from small brands that we can learn from.

How to start marketing content

Remember the quote about King Kong? Content doesn’t just appear on people’s radars. You need to put content in front of your target audience at the right time in the buying cycle. There are a number of ways you can do this, but social media and email marketing are two of the most cost-effective.

Email marketing

Email marketing may seem a bit outdated channel, but in fact, HubSpot cited Litmus’ research in its recent State of Marketing Report (2022) as returning “$42 for every $1 spent”, which is an incredible 4,200% ROI. It is clear that it is still one of the most powerful channels for promoting content. The key benefit is that it allows you to reach a wide audience with your message, can be highly targeted and is relatively low cost.

When emailing your list, make sure that you segment it so that you are only sending relevant content to those who will find it useful. No one wants to receive emails that are not relevant to them, and this will just lead to people unsubscribing from your list.

Social media

Social media is a great way to amplify your content and reach a wider audience. It allows you to connect with your audience and build relationships with them. Most platforms now have both organic and paid-for services.

Organic reach on social media has definitely been declining but that doesn’t mean that if you are on a limited budget, you shouldn’t explore this route. However, you will need to ensure that your content is optimised for each platform and is able to be consumed on-platform, rather than redirecting users off the network. Often newer social networks will have greater organic reach per follower than older ones.

Tip: Take advantage of new services or post types and use them because these will receive more reach than older formats.

Paid Social is a very complex area, and to cover everything in this article would take too much of your time. The best methodology is to start small with small budgets and then test and learn as you go. We provide paid social marketing services, so drop us a line if you would like to learn more.

Tip: Check each platform’s promotion options and bidding strategy and ensure that they are optimised for your content goals (i.e. do you want users to engage with the content, raise brand awareness, or undertake a specific action for example sign up for an event.) It will also depend on your overarching strategy as to whether you are marketing to new audiences or warming up an existing audience.

Finally, when promoting your content on social media, make sure that you are active and engaging with your audience. Don’t just post and run, take the time to respond to comments and answer any questions people have. Also, use it as a way to research your audience in more depth. Validate your content ideas before creating content and find out what your audience’s most pressing pains and needs are.

Both email marketing and social media are great ways to get your content in front of your target audience, but there are other channels you can explore as well. These include:

  • Search engine marketing
  • Guest blogging
  • Online communities
  • Forums
  • Q&A websites
  • Native advertising platforms

Measuring success

There are a number of ways that you can measure the success of your content marketing campaign. These include:

  • Website traffic
  • Social media engagement
  • Lead generation
  • Conversions (Sales)

Website traffic

One of the most basic indicators of content marketing success is website traffic. This can be measured in terms of the number of visitors to your website, the number of page views, or the amount of time spent on your site.

To get a more detailed picture of which content is performing well, you can use Google Analytics to see which pieces of content are generating the most traffic. This will give you an idea of which content is being viewed the most and is, therefore, more popular with your audience.

You can also use Google Analytics to track other metrics such as the average time spent on a page, the bounce rate, or the number of pages per session. These can all give you insights into how users are interacting with your content and whether they are finding it valuable.

Social Media Engagement

Another way to measure content marketing success is through social media engagement. This can be tracked in a number of ways, including the number of likes, shares, and comments on a piece of content, as well as the reach (the number of people who have seen the content).

Both Facebook and Twitter have their own native analytics platforms that can give you detailed insights into the performance of your content. You can also use third-party tools such as Hootsuite Insights or BuzzSumo to track social media engagement.

Lead Generation

If your content marketing campaign is focused on generating leads, then you’ll want to track the number of leads that you’re able to generate. This can be done using a tool such as Google Analytics, which will allow you to track the number of conversions (leads) that you’re able to generate from your content.

You can also use third-party lead generation tools such as LeadPages or Unbounce to track and measure the performance of your content in terms of lead generation.

Conversions (Sales)

If your content marketing campaign is focused on generating sales, then you’ll want to track the number of sales that you’re able to generate. This can be done using a tool such as Google Analytics, which will allow you to track the number of conversions (sales) that you’re able to generate from your content.

You can also use third-party sales tracking tools such as Salesforce or HubSpot Sales to track and measure the performance of your content in terms of sales.

Content marketing is a basic, but essential, marketing tactic. It involves creating and sharing valuable content with your target audience in order to attract and retain customers. In order to get started with content marketing, you’ll need to develop a content strategy, create high-quality content, and promote it through social media and other channels.

Conclusion

When creating an effective content marketing programme, there are a few things to remember. First, you’ll need to identify your target audience and what needs and wants they have. Once you know this, you can create content that is tailored to their needs and wants. Additionally, you’ll need to promote your content through social media and other channels in order to reach your target audience. Finally, you can measure the success of your content marketing campaign by tracking metrics such as website traffic, social media engagement, lead generation, and conversions.

If you would like to learn more about content marketing strategy please just drop us a line.

Content Marketing FAQs

What is the definition of content marketing?

Content marketing is a strategic marketing approach that focuses on creating and distributing valuable, relevant, and consistent content to attract and retain a clearly defined audience. The primary objective is to drive profitable customer action by establishing thought leadership, building trust, and nurturing relationships with the target audience over time.

How does content marketing differ from traditional marketing methods?

A: Traditional marketing methods often rely on interruption techniques, such as advertisements or sales pitches, to capture the audience’s attention. In contrast, content marketing aims to attract and engage potential customers by providing them with informative, educational, or entertaining content that addresses their needs, interests, and pain points. The focus is on delivering value to the audience rather than directly promoting products or services.

What are the key benefits of implementing a content marketing strategy?

Content marketing offers several significant benefits, including increased brand awareness, improved search engine optimization (SEO), enhanced customer engagement, lead generation, and cost-effective acquisition of new customers. Additionally, a well-executed content marketing strategy can position a company as a thought leader in its industry, foster trust and credibility with the target audience, and ultimately drive business growth and profitability.

What types of content are typically used in content marketing campaigns?

A: Content marketing encompasses a wide range of content formats, such as blog posts, articles, whitepapers, case studies, e-books, infographics, videos, podcasts, webinars, and social media updates. The choice of content types depends on the target audience’s preferences, the stage of the buyer’s journey, and the specific goals of the content marketing campaign. Successful content marketers often employ a diverse mix of content formats to effectively engage and nurture their audience.

How can a company measure the success of its content marketing efforts?

A: Measuring the effectiveness of a content marketing strategy is crucial for optimizing future efforts and demonstrating its value to stakeholders. Key performance indicators (KPIs) commonly used to evaluate content marketing success include website traffic, lead generation, conversion rates, social media engagement, search engine rankings, and ultimately, revenue growth. Companies should establish specific, measurable goals and consistently track relevant metrics to assess the impact of their content marketing initiatives and make data-driven adjustments as needed.

body.raw:
Best content marketing tools – make creating high-quality content easier

As a business owner, you know that content marketing is essential for your success. But how can you be sure that your content is effective? And how can you make creating high-quality content easier?

In this article, we’ll explore the best content marketing tools for 2022 and how to use them to create high-quality content that delivers results.

  • What is credible content marketing, and why should you use it?
  • Types of content and their benefits
  • The best content marketing tools of 2022
  • Conclusion

What is credible content marketing, and why should you use it?

Content marketing is a strategic marketing approach focused on creating and distributing content. Content has to be valuable, relevant, and consistent to attract the right audience. Someone then markets this content to your audience where they are open to engaging with it.

The purpose of content marketing is to build and keep a clearly defined audience. Content marketing aims to drive profitable customer interactions in time. 

Why should you use it?

There are many benefits of content marketing, including:

  • Increasing brand awareness and affinity
  • Generate leads and sales
  • Building trust and credibility with your audience
  • Reinforce your brand message

Types of content and their benefits

There are many types of content that you might want to create. Each will have its pros and cons, but the best place to start is with your content strategy.

This will help you define how much and what type of content you should be creating. Here is a list of different content types that might need to be produced and their benefits:

  • Blog posts– Blog posts help share your brand values, build credibility, and attract new customers.
  • Videos- Videos sell emotions and engage your audience and show them your products or services in action.
  • Podcasts– Podcasts are a brilliant way to reach a wider audience and build relationships with potential customers.
  • Articles- Articles are useful in sharing your brand story, building affinity, and attracting new customers.
  • Ebooks- Ebooks are a great way to share your company’s story, build credibility, and attract new customers.
  • Whitepapers- Are a straightforward way of sharing your company’s story, building credibility, and attracting new customers.
  • Reports- These are good for sharing your company’s story, building credibility, and attracting new customers.
  • Infographics- Especially good for engagement, are sharable, and attract new customers.
  • Images- High-quality images engage your audience and show them your products or services in action.
  • Animations- Animations are engaging and can be helpful to distill complex ideas and concepts for your audience.

The best content marketing tools of 2022

With so many amazing content tools out there these days, it is hard to find the best ones. To save you the time and energy researching them all, here is our pick of the best content marketing tools split into the following categories:

  • Content research and SEO tools
  • Writing tools
  • Editing tools
  • Visual content tools
  • Podcast tools
  • Video specific tools
  • Content promotion tools

Content research tools

1. Google Keyword Planner

Google’s Keyword Planner is still the original tool for content research. It allows you to see the average monthly searches for a particular keyword, also the level of competition.

This information can help you decide whether a particular keyword is worth targeting in your content. You’ll need to create a Google Ads account and be spending on the platform to get full insights, however.

2. Ubersuggest

Neil Patel’s Ubersuggest is also good for finding long-tail keywords to use in your content. Long-tail keywords are less competitive and therefore more likely to result in organic traffic. It also lets you know how easy it is to rank for a term organically and can even return SERPS for competitors.

Recently, it has become slower and you will only receive 3 searches per day on a free account.

3. BuzzSumo

BuzzSumo allows you to see the most popular content on any topic. This is a way to discover new ideas for your content and to see what content formats are performing well on different social networks.

Currently, on the free account, you can get 10 free searches a month and can see content ideas, check domain authority, and even backlinks.

4. Google Trends

Google Trends is a great tool for understanding how the popularity of a particular keyword has changed over a period. You can see what topics are breaking out in popularity at a global level as well as regionally.

This information can help decide between two different search terms or even give you ideas for headlines.

5. Ahrefs

Ahrefs is a comprehensive SEO tool that has a huge number of features for content research.  It has a site explorer, keyword explorer, content explore, also some more technical SEO functions.

The free plan again has limited functionality, but it is worth exploring, depending on what you need.

Writing tools

1. Google Docs

Google Docs is an easy way to write and collaborate on content. It’s free to use and simple to get started with. It integrates seamlessly with other Google products like Gmail and Calendar and users can co-author content well.

2. Microsoft Word

Microsoft Word is a widely used word processing program and may be the best solution, as most people are familiar with it. It offers many features for writers. Including the ability to track changes, add comments, insert pictures and videos, and check grammar.

3. Evernote

I have been using Evernote for over a decade now. It is an amazing tool for capturing ideas and organizing your thoughts. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of features, including the ability to add images, videos, and audio files.

My most used feature is tagging things that may be useful in the future and then searching to find them when I am looking for inspiration.

4. Scrivener

Scrivener is a great tool for long-form writing projects. It helps you organize your thoughts and structure your work in a way that makes it easier to write and edit.

5. Adobe InCopy

InCopy is a very handy collaboration tool that lets copywriters style text and track changes while creative teams are working on the designs in real-time. It somehow does this without overwriting individual contributions to the piece!

Editing tools

1. ProWritingAid

ProWritingAid that I am currently trialing at the moment. It is a grammar check, style editor, and writing mentor rolled into one. Plus, it offers a variety of reports that can help you improve your writing.

2. Grammarly

Being dyslexic, I could not live without Grammarly. It catches all my grammatical errors, highlights my typos, and finally makes sure that my writing makes sense. It can also help you improve your grammar skills over time, but this is unlikely if you are dyslexic.

3. Hemingway Editor

Hemingway Editor is a useful tool for making your writing simpler and easier to read. It highlights complex sentence constructions and overused words and phrases. This can help you make your writing more concise and easier to understand.

Visual content creation tools

1. Canva

Canva is a simple tool for creating visuals for your content. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of templates for all types of content. Plus, it integrates well with other tools. Plus, it integrates well with other tools.

2. Adobe Photoshop

Adobe Photoshop is perhaps the Don of visual content tools. It offers a wide range of features and can be used to create both simple and complex visuals. If you are a design novice, there are many Adobe resources and tutorials to help you on your way.

5. Adobe Illustrator

Adobe Illustrator is a widely used program for creating vector graphics. It offers a wide range of features and can create both simple and complex visuals.

Podcast tools

1. SquadCast

SquadCast is an often used tool for recording and editing podcasts. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of features, including the ability to record remotely, which is useful if you have guests in different locations.

2. Zencastr

Zencastr is another popular podcast recording tool that offers similar features to SquadCast.

3. Audacity

Audacity is a free and open-source tool for recording and editing audio. It’s simple to use and offers a wide range of features, making it a good option for podcasting.

4. Adobe Audition

Adobe Audition is a professional-grade tool for recording and editing audio. It offers a wide range of features, making it a useful option for podcasting. However, it is more complex to use than some of the other options on this list.

4. Rev.com

Rev.com is a solid option for transcribing audio files. It’s accurate and offers a variety of features, including the ability to add timestamps and speaker labels.

Video specific tools

1. Wistia

Wistia is an all-in-one tool for hosting, analyzing, and creating video content. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of features, including the ability to add timestamps and speaker labels.

2. VideoScribe

VideoScribe is a visual tool for creating whiteboard-style animations. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of features, including the ability to add timestamps and speaker labels.

3. Adobe Premiere Pro

Adobe Premiere Pro is a professional-grade video editing tool. It’s more complex to use than some of the other options on this list, but it offers a wide range of features.

4. VidIQ

VidIQ is an analytics and SEO tool that helps you optimize your videos and grow your YouTube channel. It also allows you to track competitors and gives you content ideas based on what is working.

5. Biteable

Biteable is a simple tool for creating video content. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of templates, making it a good option for businesses and individuals who want to create professional-looking videos.

6. TubeBuddy

TubeBuddy is a tool that helps you optimize your videos for YouTube. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of features, including the ability to add timestamps and speaker labels.

Content promotion tools

1. Hootsuite

Hootsuite is an enterprise-grade tool for promoting your content. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of features, including the ability to schedule posts, track analytics, and measure engagement.

2. CoSchedule

CoSchedule is an all-in-one tool for organising and promoting your content. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of features, including the ability to schedule posts, track analytics, and measure engagement.

3. Buffer

Buffer is a useful social media toolkit for smaller businesses. It’s easy to use and offers a variety of features, including the ability to schedule posts, track analytics, measure engagement and use paid promotion.

Conclusion

Content marketing is a powerful tool that can help you achieve your business goals. By following the tips in this article, you can create effective content that will engage your audience and help you achieve your desired results. Thanks for reading and we hope this has been helpful!

body.raw:
From Vision to Victory-
Crafting branding and positioning strategies that sell

Author & Founder

Chris Talintyre

To succeed these days, founders and business owners have to go beyond just developing a great product or service—they need to craft an unforgettable brand that resonates deeply with their target audience. As Seth Godin once said, “A brand is the set of expectations, memories, stories, and relationships that, taken together, account for a consumer’s decision to choose one product or service over another.”

So let’s delve into the essentials of strategic branding and positioning, and offer actionable insights and real-world examples to help you outshine your competitors. You’ll learn the fundamental concepts of branding and positioning, why these strategies are crucial for your business success, and how to develop a winning approach that captures and retains customer loyalty.

Whether you’re a burgeoning startup founder or an established business owner looking to scale, the following sections will equip you with the strategic knowledge and tools you need to build robust brand equity, differentiate from your competitors, and forge meaningful connections with your target audience. Let’s unlock the power of strategic branding and positioning to elevate your business to new heights.

Contents

  • From Vision to Victory- Crafting branding and positioning strategies that sell
  • What is Branding and Positioning?
  • Why Branding and Positioning Matters
  • Developing a Winning Branding Strategy
  • Effective Positioning Strategies
  • Integrating Branding and Positioning into Your Marketing Efforts
  • Case Studies and Examples of Successful Branding and Positioning
  • The Importance of Continuous Improvement

Key Takeouts

This article provides crucial insights for founders and business owners aiming to understand the importance and implementation of strategic branding and positioning.

  • Understanding Branding – Branding is more than just logos or taglines; it’s about creating a unique identity and personality that distinguishes your company from its competitors. Elements like visual design, messaging, customer experience, and corporate values play a significant role.
  • Importance of Positioning – Positioning is the strategic process of establishing your brand’s unique value in the mind of your target audience.
  • To create a powerful brand, it is essential to define your brand identity, establish a relatable brand personality, and craft a compelling brand story that resonates deeply with your audience.
  • Effective Positioning Strategies – Essential strategies include identifying your unique selling proposition (USP), conducting competitor analysis, and targeting the right market segments.

What is Branding and Positioning?

Understanding Branding

Branding goes beyond just a logo or a tagline. It is the holistic approach to creating a unique identity and personality that sets your company apart from the competition. This identity is shaped by various elements such as visual design, messaging, customer experience, and even your company’s values and culture.

A strong brand conveys a promise to consumers, invoking trust, loyalty, and emotional attachment. Whether it’s through a consistent colour scheme or a distinctive voice in your communications, every aspect of your brand should cohesively tell your story and convey your mission.

The Importance of Positioning

Positioning is the strategic process of establishing your brand in the mind of your target audience. It involves identifying and communicating the unique value your product or service offers compared to competitors. Effective positioning helps you carve out a distinctive place in the marketplace, making it easier for customers to choose you over others.

Your positioning should highlight the specific needs or pain points your brand addresses and how it uniquely satisfies them. A well-articulated positioning strategy makes your brand memorable and dictates all subsequent marketing efforts.

Why Branding and Positioning Matters

1. Building Brand Equity

Brand equity refers to the value your brand adds to your product or service. It’s built through positive consumer experiences and perceptions over time. A brand with strong equity can command higher prices, achieve greater customer loyalty, and enjoy more robust market share.

2. Differentiating from Competitors

In a crowded marketplace, differentiation is crucial. Branding and positioning are tools to differentiate your offerings from those of your competitors. By clearly projecting what makes your brand unique, you make it easier for consumers to recognise why they should choose you.

3. Connection

A well-crafted brand and positioning strategy can create an emotional connection with your target audience. This connection goes beyond the functional benefits of your product or service and taps into the values, aspirations, emotional and social needs of your consumers, fostering deeper, more meaningful relationships.

Developing a Winning Branding Strategy

1. Defining Your Brand Identity

Your brand identity is the face of your business. It encompasses the visual elements like logo, colour scheme, and typography, as well as the tonal elements such as brand voice and messaging. Consistency is key; a well-defined identity helps create a cohesive and recognisable brand. This can be done in-house, or if you don’t have the resources or knowledge you could research and appoint a strategic marketing consultancy.

2. Creating a Brand Personality

Your brand personality is the human-like traits that your brand exhibits. Is your brand playful and fun, or is it more professional and serious? This personality should align with your target audience’s expectations and preferences, making your brand relatable and engaging. Creating a brand playbook at this point could be a useful exercise to articulate your identity and personality to internal staff and suppliers who provide marketing services to your company.

3. Crafting a Compelling Brand Story

A compelling brand story captivates your audience and gives them a reason to care about your brand. It should articulate your brand’s mission, vision, and values, and explain why you do what you do. An authentic and well-told brand story can resonate deeply with consumers, fostering loyalty and trust.

Effective Positioning Strategies

Identifying Your Unique Selling Proposition (USP)

Your USP is the unique benefit that sets your product or service apart from competitors. Identifying your USP is critical for effective positioning. Ask yourself: What do you offer that no one else does, or what do you do better than anyone else?

Conducting Competitor Analysis

Understanding your competitors is key to successful positioning. Conduct a thorough competitor analysis to identify their strengths and weaknesses, as well as opportunities and threats in the marketplace. This analysis can inform your positioning strategy, helping you own a distinctive place in the market. Think about what emotion you could own in the customers’ mind, for example when you think of:

  • Starbucks – Moments – Valued moments in time whether that be with friends or family.
  • IKEA – Hygge – That cosy, contented mood evoked by comfort and conviviality.
  • Nike – Individual Excellence – The slogan ‘Just do it’ epitomises this positioning inspiring action and striving for your own excellence.
  • Volvo – Safety – Volvo has been obsessed with the word since the 1940s, so much so that they invented the three-point seat belt.
  • Coca-Cola – Happiness – Campaigns such as ‘The Holidays are Coming’ outlines how they own the feeling of happiness and togetherness.
  • Apple – Simplicity – Everyone can be part of the technological future.

Targeting the Right Market Segments

Effective positioning requires targeting the market segments that will most benefit from and appreciate your offerings. Use demographic, psychographic, and behavioural data to identify these segments and tailor your messaging to resonate specifically with them.

Integrating Branding and Positioning into Your Marketing Efforts

Consistent Brand Messaging

Consistency is vital in ensuring that your brand and positioning resonate with your audience. Whether through social media, email campaigns, or in-person interactions, your messaging should be uniform across all touchpoints. This consistency strengthens brand recognition and trust. Again, make sure this is documented and circulated to anyone who is producing branded assets or creating IP for your company.

Leveraging Multiple Touchpoints

Your brand should be visible wherever your target audience is. Leverage multiple channels—social media, email, websites, print media, and physical events—to ensure that your brand message reaches your audience effectively and consistently.

Measuring and Optimising Your Strategies

To ensure the success of your branding and positioning efforts, continually measure and analyse their impact. Use metrics such as brand awareness, customer loyalty, and market share to gauge the effectiveness of your strategies. Be willing to adapt and optimise based on your findings.

Top brands like Apple, Nike, and Coca-Cola have mastered the art of branding and positioning. seo.title: How mentoring can benefit individuals and businesses?
seo.description: Discover the ways mentoring can benefit individuals and organisations. Read the facts and success stories that highlight the benefits of mentoring.

body.raw:
The business benefits of mentoring: A Win-Win for individuals and businesses

Mentoring programs are increasingly being adopted by businesses looking to boost employee performance and engagement and for good reason. When approached and delivered correctly, mentoring can produce wide and long-lasting benefits to an organisation.

The main rationale for undertaking a mentoring program is to see tangible business benefits and a return on investment. However, quantifying these benefits can be challenging. In this article, we explore the primary benefits of mentoring for businesses and how it can be a win-win for both individuals and organisations.

Talent Retention

One of the primary benefits of mentoring is that it creates deeper bonds within the organisation. Mentoring provides mentees with the support and guidance they need to succeed in developing their roles and careers. When mentees succeed within the organisational structure, they are less likely to leave to develop their careers elsewhere. This, in turn, reduces staff turnover, and the businesses can focus on developing from within rather than bringing in new faces that can have a destabilising effect at senior levels.

According to a 2006 study by Garner, retention rates were higher for both mentees (22% more) and mentors (20% more) than for employees who did not participate in a mentoring program (McCarthy Mentoring 2017).

Professional Development

Mentoring provides recipients with a unique opportunity to develop new skills, knowledge, and ways of being, as well as receive benevolent guidance and support in their career development. Those that engage with mentoring report better job satisfaction, and businesses with a successful program report improved performance. In fact, they also progress faster, “25% of employees who enrolled in a mentoring program had a salary-grade change, compared to only 5% of workers who did not participate” (McCarthy Mentoring 2017 “Why mentoring: what the stats say“).

Improved Productivity

The benefits of mentoring to business productivity are well-documented, and many Fortune 500 companies have already implemented successful mentoring programs. According to the Centre for Workplace Leadership, in 2016, “71% of Fortune 500 companies have mentoring programs” (McCarthy Mentoring 2017). This number has only increased in recent years, with 84% of Fortune 500 companies having a mentoring program last year, and 100% of Fortune 50 companies having one (Cantalupo, Forbes 2022).

Improved Morale

Mentoring empowers employees with opportunities to connect, learn, and receive guidance from more experienced colleagues. This creates a more positive and supportive work environment as a whole, which benefits organisational morale. Both mentees and mentors report having a greater sense of engagement and job satisfaction.

A study by Moving Ahead and Deloitte of 6,000 people across 40 organisations found that “87% of mentors and mentees feel empowered by their mentoring relationships and have developed greater confidence” (Dimmock 2017).

Improved Diversity in Leadership

Diversity, especially in leadership, is still an issue for many businesses. However, mentoring has been shown to be one of the most effective methods of improving diversity in companies. In fact, a recent study showed that it “boosted minority representation at the management level by 9% to 24%” and “also dramatically improved promotion and retention rates for minorities and women—15% to 38%” compared to non-mentored employees (Beheshti, Forbes 2019).

In conclusion, mentoring provides numerous benefits to both individuals and organisations, however, the organisational context has a massive bearing on the degree of success. The benefits include talent retention, professional development, improved productivity, improved morale, and improved diversity in leadership. By investing in a successful mentoring program, businesses can reap the rewards of a more engaged, productive, and diverse workforce.
