seo.description: Read on to understand how focusing on the customer journey can make your business more customer-centric and elevate your marketing.

body.raw:
Understanding the customer journey map

Author & Founder

Chris Talintyre

10 steps that explain the process of mapping the customer journey.

Introduction

As the world becomes more and more digital, the customer journey has undoubtedly become more complex. Customers now have a multitude of different touchpoints to interact with businesses, so it is imperative to understand how your business can add value at every stage of this journey to give the best experience and drive profitable interactions. This is a core piece of strategy work that we undertake at Polything.

According to 2020 global research from Salesforce,

  • 80% of customers now consider their experience with a company to be as important as its products.
  • 69% of Gen X customers prioritise convenience over brand loyalty
  • 91% of customers agree that a positive customer experience makes them more likely to purchase again.

So it is clear that the task of mapping your customer journey is critical to reaching profitable customers, satisfying their needs, and generating sales. In this article, you’ll learn about the different types of customer needs and how to map them to the customer journey, and why the process is so powerful.

  • What is a customer journey? And what does it mean?
  • What are the stages of the customer journey?
  • Start with the customer and their needs
  • How to map the customer journey
  • Why is it important

Customer Journey Definition

A customer journey is the series of interactions a customer has with a brand, product, or service. It includes all touchpoints, both direct (like contacting customer service) and indirect (such as hearing about the brand at an event). Customer journey mapping involves documenting and analysing these steps to understand and enhance customer experiences.

Customer Journey Types

There are three types: Basic, Complex, and Transactional, each varying in complexity and decision-making:

  • The Basic Customer Journey is the journey that the majority of customers take. It is the simplest and most common type of customer journey.
  • The Complex Customer Journey is the journey that a minority of customers take. It is more complex because the customer has to overcome more obstacles or make more decisions.
  • The Transactional Customer Journey is the journey a customer takes when making a purchase.

But as channels have proliferated and customers’ needs have evolved into a complex system of interactions, it is best to consider these types of journeys as archetypes, rather than true to life.

What are the stages of the journey?

There are many ways of defining this, and we have developed our own methodology for customer journey mapping designed for direct-to-consumer brands. However, it is generally accepted that there are four main stages of mapping:

  • The Awareness stage is the stage where the customer becomes aware of the problem they need to solve or the opportunity they need to take advantage of.
  • The Consideration stage is the stage where the customer starts researching solutions to their problem or opportunity.
  • The Purchase stage is the stage where the customer buys the product or service.
  • The Loyalty stage is the stage where the customer becomes a repeat customer or a brand advocate.

A quick Google search will reveal thousands of styles of different customer journey mapping stages and templates, but if you are just starting HubSpot has 7 simple user journey map templates that you can download for free to get started. user

Start with the customer and their needs

Before starting to understand the journey itself, it is really important to immerse yourself in the world of your customers and view your product or service through their lens. The first thing to look at when doing this, is their needs and motivations, as this is what drives consumer behaviour. Here are some types of needs to consider:

  • Functional Needs are the needs that the customer has to solve a problem or take advantage of an opportunity.
  • Social Needs are the needs that the customer has to interact with other people.
  • Emotional Needs are the needs that the customer has to feel a certain way.
  • Experiential Needs are the needs that the customer has to have a certain experience.

It is essential to understand these needs as they related to different customers or personas before embarking on a customer journey mapping exercise.

How to map the customer journey

Here are the 10 main steps that we undertake as part of a customer journey mapping project:

  1. Define your goals
  2. Start with personas and jobs
  3. List all current touchpoints
  4. Define the customer journey
  5. Review your journeys and critique them
  6. Highlight areas where too much resource is committed
  7. Highlight areas where value can be added
  8. Create a current state map
  9. Create a future state map
  10. Use and review maps regularly

1. Define your goals

The first step is to define your goals and examine them. What do you want to achieve with the customer journey map? What business problem are you hoping to solve? Is this the right approach for that problem?

There are many other strategic frameworks out there, and maybe they are more practical for solving your current issues. Before moving on to the next step it is also useful to consider who you want to take on the journey, which stakeholders will give the greatest insight, and which will lead the project towards actionable change.

2. Start with personas and jobs

The second step is to refer back to the customer research that you have undertaken earlier. At this point for each customer type or persona, you should have a list of the types of needs they have as well as the jobs or goals they are trying to achieve. Also, consider the pain points that they will reach certain parts of the consumer journey.

It is worthwhile at this stage to think about whether your business is satisfying the wrong needs or even whether the job your service or product solves is even relevant at all. Quite often at this stage, it will highlight areas of your product roadmap that are out of sync with your customers.

Next, consider the stages they will go through when trying to solve their problem or achieve their goal.

Ask your team:

  • What is the most important job this persona is looking for help with?
  • Are all the steps needed?
  • Could your business disrupt these steps to provide a better service?
  • Are we speaking to this persona at the right time, through the right channels?

It can be helpful at this stage to create a persona template that you can use to map out the different characteristics of your persona. HubSpot also has a useful tool for creating personas.

3. List all current touchpoints

The third step is to list out all the current touchpoints that the customer has with your brand. This includes both digital and physical touchpoints.

What is a customer journey touchpoint?

A touchpoint is any interaction the customer has with your brand. This could be the first time they see an advert, the moment they land on your website, the point of sale, or even a post-purchase follow-up call or email. It is important to consider all the touchpoints in the journey as this will help you understand how customers interact with your brand and where the biggest opportunities or pain points are.

To do this, you will need to consider the customer journey from the persona’s perspective and understand how they interact with your brand at each stage.

It is helpful just to list every single touchpoint and not examine them at this point, as you will likely find that you have many more touchpoints than you initially thought

4. Define the customer journey

The next step is to define the user journey map for each of your personas. This will involve creating a separate customer journey map for each persona, detailing their individual jobs, needs, and pains, as well as defining the stages they typically go through that leads to a purchase.

Focus on getting a basic Journey down first, before considering optimal or broken journeys.

The easiest way to do this is with sticky notes, or a virtual whiteboard if your team is working remotely.

5. Review your journeys and critique them

Then it is time to review your current state user journey map and critique them through the lens of value. Understand if and where your business currently adds value in the journey.

What does this mean?

Ask your team the following questions:

  • What value are you providing the customer at each stage of the consumer’s journey?
  • How could you improve this?
  • Are there any areas where you are not providing enough value or where the customer may be getting frustrated?
  • How are you addressing their pains?
  • Are there stages that could be removed or simplified?
  • Is there a bigger job you could solve that would create more value?

6. Highlight areas where too much resource is committed

Now that you know what your customers want and the ways they tend to interact with your business, it is time to optimise the customer journey to serve their needs.

This could mean removing lengthy call times or multiple emails back and forth. Or cutting areas from your marketing spend. Identifying these areas can help you to streamline the journey, improve the customer experience, and make your business more profitable.

7. Highlight areas where value can be added

This could be anything from adding a live chat function to your website to providing more helpful information at key points in the journey, or marketing via a channel that has not been used to date. It also might mean creating informative content or building a helpful tool for your customers.

Ultimately, it might involve evolving your product or creating a new one to take advantage of a new opportunity.

8. Create a current state map

The next stage is to create a current state map, or user experience map of how your business services now. Make sure that this is visual and easy to understand so that everyone in your business can refer to it and more importantly use it. This will help you to understand where your consumer journey currently sits at a given point in time.

It is also useful to refer back to this type of map later so that you can chart your business’ progress and development.

9. Create a future state map

The penultimate step is to create a future state map of how it could work by creating more value to customers. This will involve brainstorming new and innovative ways to improve the customer experience and adding value at every stage of the journey. The insights that you have already generated will be useful here.

Once you have a list of potential improvements, get your team to rank them by considering how helpful these are to each persona in achieving their goal, or undertaking their job.

As with the current state map then create a visual map of this journey including only the top five innovations as agreed by the whole team.

10. Make sure these maps are used and reviewed regularly

Finally, make sure that these maps are used and reviewed regularly. They should be living documents that are constantly updated as the customer journey evolves. Reviewing the maps regularly will help you to identify any new opportunities or areas for improvement and highlight new jobs that your company could solve.

Why is it important?

The customer journey is important because it helps you service your existing customers well, and hopefully better than your competitors. It makes organisations focus on the customer’s needs, and develop communication that fits those needs. It also helps you improve the customer’s experience and lifetime value.

Finally, undertaking a customer journey regularly can help you identify potentially gaming-changing new business opportunities. Being more customer-focused has many more benefits besides. If you are interested in learning more feel free to drop us a line.

Is your brand truly distinctive?

Many brands struggle to carve out a unique space in their market. Your brand’s unique value proposition should be a shining beacon, not a distant glimmer.

Our diagnostic tool measures how well your brand establishes a unique emotional connection maintains consistency across all touchpoints, and adapts to market changes—all the while staying true to its core identity.

Dare to find out the truth with our Distinctive Brand Index assessment. The results might surprise you!

Take the Assessment

FAQs

What is a customer journey map?

A customer journey map is a visual representation of the complete end-to-end experience a customer has with a company, product, or service. It depicts the various touchpoints and interactions a customer encounters throughout their journey, from initial awareness to post-purchase support and advocacy. By mapping out this journey, businesses can gain insights into customer behaviour, pain points, and opportunities for improvement.

Why is creating a customer journey map crucial for businesses?

Developing a customer journey map is essential for several reasons. Firstly, it helps companies understand their customers’ perspectives, motivations, and expectations at each stage of their interaction. This understanding enables businesses to identify areas where the customer experience may be lacking or where additional support or resources are needed. Secondly, a well-crafted customer journey map facilitates cross-functional collaboration within an organisation, ensuring that all departments are aligned in delivering a consistent and seamless experience. Additionally, it serves as a powerful tool for identifying opportunities for innovation, streamlining processes, and optimising customer touchpoints.

What are the typical stages included in a customer journey map?

While customer journey maps can vary depending on the industry and specific business, they typically include the following stages: Awareness (initial discovery of the product or service), Consideration (researching and evaluating options), Purchase (the decision-making and transactional phase), Experience (using the product or service), and Loyalty (post-purchase support, advocacy, and potential repurchase). Each stage encompasses various touchpoints, such as website visits, social media interactions, customer service interactions, and product usage experiences.

How can businesses gather data to create an accurate customer journey map?

To create an accurate and insightful customer journey map, businesses should leverage a combination of data sources and research methods. This may include website analytics, customer feedback surveys, social media monitoring, customer interviews, focus groups, and observation of customer interactions. Additionally, businesses can leverage internal data from various departments, such as sales, customer service, and marketing, to gain a comprehensive understanding of customer touchpoints and pain points.

How can a customer journey map be utilised to improve the overall customer experience?

A well-designed customer journey map serves as a powerful tool for improving the overall customer experience in several ways. It enables businesses to identify and address pain points, bottlenecks, or areas of frustration throughout the journey. Additionally, it helps organizations prioritise and allocate resources more effectively by focusing on the touchpoints that have the greatest impact on customer satisfaction. Furthermore, a customer journey map can inform the development of targeted marketing campaigns, personalized experiences, and tailored communications that resonate with customers at specific stages of their journey.

seo.title: Marketing Consultants – How to find the right one
seo.description: Wondering how to find and work with a marketing consultant? Look no further, this guide will teach you everything you need to know.

body.raw:
Everything you wanted to know about working with Marketing Consultants

Introduction

If you’re like most business owners, you probably wear a lot of hats. You’re responsible for marketing your company, generating leads, selling products or services, and handling customer service – just to name a few things. It’s no wonder that so many founders of direct-to-consumer businesses feel overwhelmed and stressed out.

One way to take some of the pressure off is to hire a marketing consultant, which allows you to focus on growing your business rather than building your marketing function. The benefits of working with an independent practitioner are access to specialist marketing skills and knowledge, fresh ideas and perspectives, an objective viewpoint, additional capacity, and bandwidth. Over time a good independent consultant should be able to help you build your knowledge and a marketing function in-house.

Contents

  1. What do they do?
  2. How can they help your business grow?
  3. What are the benefits to your business?
  4. How to find and work with one
  5. Closing Thoughts

What is a marketing consultant? And what do they do?

They are independent professionals who will come into your business on a temporary or part-time basis to grow your marketing function. They offer specialist marketing skills and knowledge, as well as fresh ideas and perspectives. They can help businesses to create and execute their marketing plan more effectively and can provide guidance and support throughout the process. As experts in their field, are also able to refine your value proposition and deliver you a cost-effective go-to-market strategy for your business.

They will usually start by auditing your customers, business, and any marketing that has been done to date, before formulating a strategic direction based on your business plan, followed by a marketing plan. They can often help you with executing that plan, whether that be with in-house staff or freelancers from their network.

How can they help your business grow?

Marketing consultants can help your business grow by providing a fresh perspective on your marketing, and offering innovative directions, or technical solutions that you might not have thought about. They can also help you to execute your marketing plan more effectively, and provide guidance and support on how to streamline the process and make the most out of your budget.

With their extensive experience, they should be able to make sure that you have a good product-market fit and make sure that your business objectives are underpinned by the correct level of marketing support. They should also be able to help you find new customer segments that maybe you have never considered, and help you understand which customers are profitable and therefore who to focus your marketing on.

What are the benefits to your business?

Perspective

The key advantage of working with a freelance marketing consultant is that they are annexed to your business and should give you an honest appraisal of where opportunities might lie, as well as highlight the shortcomings at a strategic and tactical level. Very few employees and even fewer agencies will feel comfortable giving this type of feedback. They will also be much more familiar with the marketing and consumer trends as well as the consumer research that is available.

Diagnosing Problems

A good consultant should have enough practical experience to give you absolute clarity on what is working and what is not, furthermore what you need to do to fix things. From broken campaigns, teams, conversion funnels, or communication, good practitioners should have a wide breadth of knowledge of the whole marketing function to be able to diagnose and fix all marketing-related problems often saving you huge amounts of money in the process.

Capacity

A consultant is a great option if your company is growing, you are strapped for resources, or you have been unable to hire anyone of the right calibre in-house. They should be able to help plug the gaps in more senior functions such as strategy development and budgeting, but also help you move more quickly by implementing a marketing plan. Many will also be able to make introductions to key personnel you need to hire or even build virtual teams on your behalf.

Accountability

Most practitioners have previously been in senior marketing in-house roles, so they should more than comfortable with assuming responsibility within your organization. They will be adept at delivering complex marketing plans and keeping your staff and third-party suppliers and agencies on track. They should be a safe pair of hands that you can rely on, but also flag issues with delivery whether that be inside or outside your organization. A surprising benefit of using an independent consultant is that they may even keep you more accountable!

How to find and work with a consultant

n today’s fast-paced business environment, bringing in a consultant can be a game-changer. Whether you need help with marketing strategy, business mentoring, or creative production, the right consultant can provide the expertise and perspective to elevate your business. Here’s a straightforward guide to finding and effectively working with a consultant.

Finding the Right Consultant

  1. Identify Your Needs:
    • Before you start your search, clearly define the problem you need to solve. Are you looking for marketing strategy, business coaching, or creative services? Being specific about your needs will help you find a consultant with the right expertise.
  2. Seek Recommendations:
    • Ask your network for recommendations. Colleagues, industry peers, or professional groups can provide valuable insights and referrals.
  3. Research Online:
    • Use platforms like LinkedIn, professional association directories, and consultancy websites. Look for consultants who specialise in your area of need and check their credentials and testimonials.
  4. Evaluate Their Expertise:
    • Once you have a shortlist, evaluate their expertise. Look for case studies, client testimonials, and relevant experience. Don’t hesitate to ask for references.
  5. Interview Candidates:
    • Schedule interviews to discuss your project and gauge their approach. This is also an opportunity to assess their communication skills and compatibility with your team.

Working Effectively with a Consultant

At the end of the engagement, evaluate the outcomes against your initial objectives. Reflect on what worked well and what could be improved for future collaborations.

Set Clear Objectives – Clearly define the goals and expected outcomes of the consultancy engagement. What does success look like for you? Setting clear objectives helps align expectations and provides a roadmap for the consultant.

Establish a Scope of Work – Develop a detailed scope of work outlining the tasks, deliverables, timeline, and budget. This document serves as a reference point throughout the engagement.

Communicate Regularly – Maintain open and regular communication. Schedule check-ins to discuss progress, address any issues, and adjust plans as necessary. Clear communication ensures that everyone is on the same page.

Foster Collaboration – Encourage collaboration between your team and the consultant. Their insights are most valuable when integrated into your existing operations and strategy. Create a collaborative environment where ideas can be freely exchanged.

Monitor Progress – Track the consultant’s progress against the established objectives and milestones. Regularly review the impact of their work and provide feedback. This helps in making any necessary adjustments promptly.

Evaluate and Reflect – At the end of the engagement, evaluate the outcomes against your initial objectives. Reflect on what worked well and what could be improved for future collaborations.

Tips for working with a marketing consultant

If you’re looking for help with your marketing, a marketing consultant can be a great resource. Here are 5 tips for working with them:

  1. Make sure the consultant has the right skillset and experience for your business.
  2. Meet with the consultant to discuss your objectives and expectations.
  3. Give the consultant access to key personnel and marketing materials.
  4. Provide the consultant with a clear brief or marketing consultant job description.
  5. Keep the lines of communication open throughout the length of the engagement.
  6. Ensure that they have professional indemnity or marketing consultant insurance.

By following these tips, you can ensure that you get the most out of the relationship..

Questions to ask before hiring marketing consultants

They can be a great resource for businesses looking to improve their marketing strategies. However, it is important to ask the right questions before hiring one in order to ensure that they are the right fit for your business. Here are 5 questions you should ask before hiring:

  • What marketing experience do they have?
  • What marketing approach do they take? And why?
  • What are their fees and terms?
  • What is their availability?
  • How well do they understand your industry or sector?

If you are looking for help with marketing, going this route can be a great resource. By following these tips and asking the right questions, you can make sure that you hire the best person for your business.

Closing Thoughts

As marketing evolves, marketing consultants and consultancies are becoming more central to building a modern marketing program. To stay ahead of the curve, marketing consultancies are constantly embracing new marketing channels, technology, and strategies. They should also focus on building strong relationships with their clients so that they can better understand their needs and provide tailored advice. Finally, marketing consultancies are starting to invest in new technologies and >They can be a great asset to any business, but it is important to find the right consultant for your specific needs. To find the best person for your business, you should meet with them to discuss your objectives and expectations, give them access to key personnel and marketing materials, and provide them with a clear brief.

Most practitioners will respond with a statement of work that outlines their responsibilities and the specific work they will undertake. Once you have found the right person, be sure to keep the lines of communication open throughout the length of the engagement. By following these tips, you can ensure that you get the most out of working with one.

seo.title: Direct marketing in a recession – The key benefits to your business
seo.description: In this article, we will discuss why direct marketing in a recession is an effective way to beat a downturn. And how to market in a downturn.

body.raw:
Why direct marketing is more effective than traditional methods during a recession

Introduction

It’s no secret that the current economy is tough, with one in four businesses reporting that inflation was their main concern and UK GDP falling 0.3% in April 2022. With consumers also feeling the pinch and spending less, it is no wonder that business owners are starting to feel concerned that there is a recession on the way. But while many businesses are focusing on ways to save money, there are still opportunities for those who know how to take advantage of them. One such opportunity is direct marketing.

Many studies including the Harvard Business Review have found that direct marketing in a recession is a good thing, and slashing all marketing in a recession is a mistake. However, the companies that refocus their budgets and efforts on measurable forms of marketing like direct marketing, weather the economic storm better, build market share and flourish after a recession. Building and maintaining strong brands also remains to this day the best way of weathering an economic downturn.

In this article, we will discuss why it is so important to continue direct marketing in a recession, how to it is an effective way of beating a downturn, and why direct marketing is the best method of doing this.

  1. What direct marketing is
  2. The benefits of direct marketing over traditional methods
  3. How to direct market in a downturn
  4. Tips for creating a direct marketing campaign that works

1. What direct marketing is

Direct marketing is a form of marketing that involves direct communication with potential customers. This can be done in a variety of ways, including postal mail, email, phone calls, SMS, and advertising. It is a way of marketing that allows businesses to target specific consumers based on their interests, which can result in higher conversion rates.

2. The benefits of direct marketing over traditional methods

There are many benefits to direct marketing over traditional methods, particularly in a recession. One of the main benefits is that it is more cost-effective. By cutting out the middleman, businesses can save money on advertising costs and pass those savings along to the consumer.

Another benefit of direct marketing is that it is more targeted and offers measurable returns. Businesses can target specific consumers based on their interests, which can result in higher conversion rates. Additionally, direct marketing allows businesses to track results and ROI more effectively, making it easier to adjust and improve campaigns incrementally.

3. How to direct market in a downturn

Now that we’ve covered the basics of direct marketing and some of the benefits it offers, let’s take a look at how direct marketing works in a downturn.

One of the most important things to remember when direct marketing in a recession or downturn is to understand the psychology behind economics. It is also crucial to adopt a consumer-focused mindset.

Downturn Psychology

Each recession is unique with different factors contributing to the downturn. The recession of 2009 was driven by banking practices and bad debt, The Great Depression on the other hand was a fragile post-war economy, speculation, and mistakes made by the US Federal Bank. These factors will impact consumers very differently and will determine in part their mindset as well as how they behave.

How does consumer spending change during a recession?

Consumers no matter how affluent, tend to categorise their expenditure in the following way:

  • Essentials – These are the items that consumers cannot go without such as food, water, shelter, and clothing.
  • Discretionary – These are the items that consumers do not necessarily need but make their life more comfortable. These include items such as entertainment, eating out, holidays, and new clothes.
  • Deferred – These are the items that consumers may want but due to the current circumstances, they are not able or willing to purchase them. These include big-ticket items such as a new car or home improvements.
  • Expendables – These items are neither essential nor discretionary for living a full life, and are the first things to be cut when consumers are feeling the pinch. These include items such as luxury goods, eating out, and subscriptions.

To succeed with direct marketing in a recession, it is crucial to understand which of these categories your service or product sits in and formulate a recession strategy based on how consumers will treat spending in your vertical.

For example, if you are a luxury goods manufacturer you may need to consider new markets where the downturn has had less of an impact or economies that have not been impacted at all. Or, if you sell a discretionary product, you may change your messaging to suggest that your product is a little luxury that makes life worth living.

Wherever your product or service falls in consumers spending priorities, acknowledge it and plan according, even if the means slashing budgets early. Whether or not you have products in demand during recession there will be a strategy that works for you.

Portfolio Audit

If you have more than one product it is really important to perform a portfolio audit to understand which of your products and services has the highest cost base, profit-based, as well as long-term market potential.

This is where potentially hard decisions need to be made. It may be that you have a new launch product that everyone is behind, but it doesn’t have long-term growth potential and in the short term it is going to be a big drain on your resources. Sometimes closing this type of enterprise might be the right decision, or just servicing existing customers might be viable.

This will depend on your own business and circumstances. Only you will know the right thing to do.

Opportunites

Next it is time to look at the positive and discover the opportunities that sit within your portfolio of products or services. If you only have one this is still a useful exercise to undertake.

For each product, of service sketch out a business model canvas and then decide how things could be done differently. Ask yourself the following questions:

  • Could we generate recurring revenues by converting products into services?
  • Could we better integrate our products or services?
  • Are there additional customer needs we could satisfy?
  • Could we add extensions to our Value Proposition?
  • There are other jobs could we do on behalf of consumers?
  • Can we replace one-time transactions with recurring revenues?
  • Are there other elements that customers be willing to pay for?
  • Could we standardise or cut some of our Key Activities?
  • We can benefit from a growing market?
  • Could channel efficiency or effectiveness could be improved?
  • Could we use less costly resources to achieve the same result?

Once complete you should have a list of key opportunities that you can then rank by the impact that they will have on your business.

Recession marketing strategy

Now that you have all the information together it is time to formulate a recession-beating strategy. First focus on your portfolio and in light of all the work that you have done, be honest about your prospects.

Better to discontinue some product lines now and thrive, than have your whole company brought down by the products or services that clearly will not weather the storm.

Next, consider where you can place your investment in marketing. Take scalpel to the rest of your budget and work out the bare minimum you need to spend on things like communications, display media, and any long-term branding projects that are underway.

To counteract this also consider how and if you can discount your product. Consumers in a recession do appreciate value, so ensure that your offering does represent good, or better value than before.

Then once this is done consider whether based on your existing metrics how much of this could or should be reallocated to your direct marketing budget.

Refer back to your consumer psychology and opportunities and start to formulate some hypotheses of direct marketing strategies you could undertake to increase sales.

Finally, formalise the budgets for this activity and ringfence it for the long term, there is nothing worse than pulling more spending later, only to discover that if you had continued for another couple of months you would have seen the return.

Tips for creating a direct marketing campaign that works

Now that you have a direct marketing budget, it is time to make sure that your campaigns generate a positive return on investment.

Carefully consider the following:

  • Who is your target market?
  • What are their needs?
  • What are their buying triggers?
  • How will you reach them?
  • What channels will you use?
  • What type of message will resonate?
  • What offer will you make?
  • What call to action will you include?
  • How will you measure success?

Once you have answers to all of these questions, you can start to develop your tactical direct marketing campaigns.

Remember to test, measure, and iterate as you go. And direct marketing can be a great way to reach consumers during a recession.

Conclusion

Committing to marketing spend in a recession can feel like a daunting if not foolhardy prospect, but the research is there to show that it works. Direct marketing might not be the first thing that comes to mind when you think about how to weather a recession, it can be a powerful tool in your arsenal.

By targeting the right consumers and cutting out intermediaries, businesses can save money on marketing costs, build better products and pass some savings along to the consumer.

So if you are looking for a business strategy during recession, or would like case studies of how direct marketing can help, please drop us a line.

body.raw:
Fractional Marketing Expert UK – Marketing Experts for Fraction of the Cost

How to choose the right fractional marketing expert for your needs

The field of marketing has radically changed in recent years and has moved well beyond the remit of just sales support, or being a major cost burden to your business. More and more businesses are recognising the impact that marketing (particularly Directors and CMO’s), can have on their business as a whole. From valuable input into business strategy setting, developing and launching new products, and helping raise investment. They can also take ownership of business growth and profitability, as well as P&L. This means that marketing functions are now becoming more integrated in business practice than ever before.

Linkedin currently lists over 26,000 senior C-suite CMOs in the UK, which is a testament to the importance that businesses place on these roles to drive business growth. This is great if your business can afford to recruit a skilled marketer with board-level experience, but what if your business can not bear the cost of a highly-paid executive, or your business is not big enough to justify a full-time role?

From CMO’s to channel specialists, this is where our fractional marketing experts come in. In this helpful guide, you’ll learn everything you need to know about fractional marketing, including the benefits it can offer your business. Plus, we’ll help you choose the right one for your needs, so you can get started reaping the benefits of this new way of working.

We hope you are enjoying this content and finding it valuable. To explore a bespoke solution tailored to your company’s needs please drop us a line or book a call.

Ready to find out more? 

Book a call
  • What is a fractional marketing expert?
  • The benefits of using a fractional marketing expert
  • How to choose the right one for your needs
  • Tips on how to get started
  • Conclusion

What is a fractional marketing expert?

A fractional marketing expert is a senior marketer hired part-time to plan, develop, and launch marketing campaigns. They guide and manage marketing departments, providing high-level expertise without the full-time cost. This role benefits small to medium-sized businesses and startups.

What experience do they usually have?

There are lots of myths around this, but a fractional marketing director is usually a senior marketer who has previously worked in-house at a variety of companies; choosing one who has the correct background for your business will be critical to success. Most will have occupied board-level positions, managed multi-functional teams, and will have experience in building new teams. They will be adept at stakeholder management and also be able to influence at a C-suite level as well as motivate a marketing team.

Engaging with one would typically involve hiring them to work with your company on a part-time or project basis. This can be an especially beneficial arrangement for small and medium-sized businesses or startups that may not have the budget to hire a full-time marketing consultant or director.

Fractional marketing experts can be used to help set strategy, build virtual or in-house marketing teams, oversee and manage marketing plan execution and develop new product offerings.

The benefits of using a fractional marketing expert

There are many benefits of working this way, including:

Flexible Commitment

Access to experienced marketing talent without the high cost or commitment of a full-time hire. This gives your business flexibility in your approach and you can increase or decrease your commitment over time based on your needs. Your business will benefit from the insight and experience that an expert can bring, but only pay for the time you need.

Scalability

The ability to scale your marketing efforts up or down as needed, without a long-term commitment. Many professionals will be prepared to work on a project-by-project basis allowing you to link costs directly with results, making this a very efficient way to work. This can be a great way to start the relationship, by getting some short-term help and building confidence in their abilities.

Experience

A good fractional marketing expert will have also been in the industry long enough to have a wealth of contacts that you can utilise as a part of your business. They will be able to identify what functions and activities you are currently missing in your existing plan.

They will know which marketing suppliers and tech are best suited to your use case, as well as be able to bring in specialists in areas such as SEO or PPC to supplement your own team. If you have limited skills in-house, they can even build you an outsourced fractional marketing team.

Perspective

Perspective is an often under-recognised benefit of using a fractional marketing expert. Because they work on your behalf but are annexed to your business, you will benefit from their greater objectivity.

Quite often an external perspective can be useful to identify issues within your business, that a full-time employee may not feel comfortable voicing. Also due to the nature of working this way a fractional marketer will not get caught up in the politics of your business, and are there to deliver rather than climb a corporate ladder or bolster their CV.

As a result, they will focus on your business needs and the role you have assigned them to deliver on your objectives.

Marketing Rigour

A good fractional marketing expert will be able to enforce some rigour into your marketing function. Marketing ultimately exists to grow your business profitably. Having a senior manager looking after the needs of your business, rather than working on vanity projects, will have a positive impact on your bottom line.

Tasks such as implementing processes, measuring effectiveness, customer research, and understanding lifetime value should become much clearer within your business. They will also instil this rigour within your existing team, as well as be able to teach best practices and call out poor performance.

These are just some of the few benefits your business will enjoy by using a fractional marketing expert, but if you are still not sure, there are some key signs that your business could need one.

Choosing the right one for your needs

When choosing a fractional marketing expert, it’s important to consider their skills, experience, and areas of expertise. You’ll also want to make sure that they’re a good fit for your company culture and that they understand your business goals.

Here are a few tips to help you choose the right person for your needs:

1. Define your needs. Before you start your search, take some time to think about what you need from them. What skills and expertise do you require? What kind of personality do you want them to have? What is your budget? Once you have a good understanding of your needs, you’ll be able to narrow down your search.

2. Do your research. Once you know what you’re looking for, it’s time to start your research. Check out websites like LinkedIn and Glassdoor to find fractional marketing experts in your industry or region. You can also ask for recommendations from friends or business contacts who have used one in the past.

3. Compare proposals. Once you’ve found a few fractional marketing experts that you’re interested in working with, ask them to provide you with a proposal outlining their services and fees. This will give you a chance to compare apples to apples and make sure that you’re getting the best value for your money.

4. Ask for references. Before making your final decision, be sure to ask each of the prospects you’re considering for a list of references. This will give you a chance to speak with other business owners or marketing professionals who have worked with them in the past and get a sense of their quality of work and professionalism.

Tips on how to get started 

Once you’ve found the perfect fractional marketing expert for your needs, it’s time to get started. Here are a few tips to help you get the most out of your partnership:

1. Set clear goals. Before getting started, take some time to sit down with them and set clear goals for your marketing strategy. What are your business objectives? What are your targets for leads, sales, or website traffic? Having a clear understanding of what you want to achieve will help you focus your efforts and measure success.

2. Communicate regularly. One of the benefits of working with a fractional marketing expert is that you can tap into their expertise and experience. But in order to get the most out of your partnership, you need to communicate with them regularly. Keep them updated on your business goals and progress, and let them know about any changes or challenges you’re facing.

3. Be open to feedback. A good fractional marketing expert will be honest with you about what’s working and what isn’t. They may also have suggestions for how you can improve your marketing strategy. Be open to their feedback and take it to heart; after all, they’re the experts in their field.

4. Celebrate successes. When you achieve your goals, take a moment to celebrate your success. This will not only motivate you to keep going, but it will also show your hire that you value their expertise and are willing to listen to their advice.

Conclusion

By following these tips, you can get the most out of your fractional marketing partnership and achieve your business goals. If you’re ready to find a fractional marketing expert to help grow your business, get in touch with us today. We’ll be happy to chat with you about your needs and connect you with someone who will be great for your business.

seo.title: Fractional Marketing Experts – 7 Wild myths Explained
seo.description: Fractional marketing experts have become a popular recently. But there are still many myths, so let s debunk them and set the record straight.

body.raw:
Fractional Marketing Experts: The facts behind the myths

Introduction

Fractional marketing experts have become a popular choice for businesses of all sizes and budgets. But there are still many myths and misconceptions about them.

People often think that they are expensive and only for businesses with a lot of money to spend. But that’s not always the case.

Fractional marketing experts can benefit businesses of all sizes and budgets to get the most out of their marketing efforts. So let’s debunk some of these myths and set the record straight.

Myths and Reality

Myth 1: Fractional directors are only for big businesses with deep pockets

Reality: Fractional marketing directors can help businesses of all sizes get the most out of their marketing budget. Whether you have a large budget or a small one, a fractional marketing expert can help you create a strategic plan that fits your needs and gets the most bang for your buck.

Many will have worked at or with startups and will have experience in intensively bootstrapping a business to profitability and scale.

Myth 2: Fractional marketing experts are too expensive

Reality: The cost of a fractional marketing expert is often less than the cost of hiring a full-time employee. When you hire a fractional marketing expert, you only pay for the time and expertise that you need. This can save you a lot of money in the long run.

The added benefit is that you will have a senior leader in your business who will be able to define marketing strategy and ensure you have the best product-market fit.

Myth 3: Fractional marketing experts are a luxury

Reality: Fractional marketing experts can save you money. By helping you create a plan and execute it efficiently, a fractional marketing expert can help you avoid costly mistakes.

They are acutely aware of their billing rates, and a good practitioner will almost always ensure that they have saved your business more than they have cost. Alternatively made you a positive return on investment in terms of additional sales.

In fact, not having a senior marketing leader in your business could cost you money in the long run, through missed opportunities, lack of direction, and lack of accountability in your marketing function.

Myth 4: Fractional marketing experts won’t understand my business

Reality: Fractional marketing experts are experienced professionals who have worked with businesses of all sizes and industries.

They understand the challenges that businesses face and actually, as part of their engagement they will want to analyse your marketplace and competition. In this capacity, their distance from the day-to-day of your business is an advantage and will yield better opportunity insights.

Myth 5: We can undertake digital transformation ourselves

Reality: With their extensive experience, they can help you navigate the digital landscape and find the right tools and strategies for your business. Digital transformation is a complex process, and it’s constantly changing. A fractional marketing expert can save you time and money by avoiding the pitfalls that less experienced marketers might make.

Myth 6: Without a formal full-time role fractional marketing experts are unable to affect change.

Reality: Fractional marketing experts are change agents. Unlike consultants, who simply offer advice, fractional marketing experts roll up their sleeves and help you implement the changes that they recommend.

This hands-on approach ensures that the changes are made efficiently and effectively. Also not being engaged in your business permanently full-time means that they can push changes that are unpopular but are in the best interests of your business.

Myth 7: Fractional marketing experts can only help if we have a marketing-related issue.

Reality: This is a moot point, but most experts will have had the experience of managing multi-disciplined teams across, technical, product, development, operations, and even customer service.

They often become the CEO’s right-hand person, managing strategic and operational issues as they relate to marketing. This provides an invaluable outside perspective that can help businesses of all sizes solve problems and achieve their goals.

Conclusion

Fractional marketing experts are a great choice for businesses of all sizes and budgets. If you’re looking to get the most out of your marketing efforts, don’t let myths hold you back.

About the author

Chris Talintyre is a fractional marketing expert with over 10 years of experience helping businesses grow. He is the founder of Polything Marketing Consultancy, a company that provides affordable and effective marketing services to businesses of all sizes. Contact him at contact@polything.co.uk.

document.title: Google business profile posts – Why you need to use them

seo.title: Google business profile posts – Why you need to use them
seo.description: Google business profile posts tips, best practices and why you should use them to drive brand awareness and affinity for your business.

body.raw:
Google business profile posts tips and guidelines

Introduction

Google Business Profile (formerly Google My Business) is a great way for businesses to connect with customers and promote their products or services. By creating a Google Business Profile and posting regularly, businesses can improve their visibility online, and build trust and credibility with potential customers. Google says “Your Business Profile on Google Search and Maps can help you attract new customers and grow your business.”

  1. What are Google business profile posts?
  2. Types of Google Profile Business Posts that you can use
  3. How to create a post
  4. Why you should use posts to promote your business:

What are Google business profile posts?

With Google business profile posts business owners can post updates about their business that are associated with their profile. These posts help existing and new customers know more about your business.

The posts are a bit like Facebook posts in that they can be reshared from your profile and posted onto other social networks or via email. Unfortunately, unlike social networks, users cannot like or comment on your posts or share within the ecosystem as users do not have their own profiles.

Users will see these posts in a variety of places including Google Maps environments including the app, SERPS, and Local Search:

Types of posts you can use:

There are a few different types of posts you can use on your Google Profile Business page.

What’s new

These posts are general updates on your business, it is easy to include photos or videos, a description together with an action button to lead users to find out more. They can be used for updates on opening hours, promotions, or things like address changes.

These types of posts are great for building brand awareness and affinity and in some countries also get surfaced automatically by Google based on your reviews rating and search intent.

Events

If you’re hosting an event, using Google Business Profile is a great way to promote it. You can share event details, such as the date, time (start and end), location, and a brief description. As with What’s New posts, these posts can include photos, videos, descriptions, and action buttons.

Customers will be able to see your event posts in Google Maps and Google Search. Events under some circumstances can be surfaced on your business in the Overview section of your business profile, Google does not publish what the criteria are for this to happen, however. All events will appear in the Events section of your knowledge panel in SERPS.

These posts are great for driving action and attendance as well as building affinity with your audience.

Offers

You can use these types of posts to share offers with your customers. As with the previous post types, you will be able to include the same information and media, but with this type of post, you will also need to include a title and start and end dates for the offer. In addition, you can also include links, Ts&Cs, and even give your offer a coupon code for redemptions.

These posts offer more flexibility to craft a great offer, as well as appear near the top of your profile in the knowledge panel. They will also appear in the Updates tab section nearer the bottom of the profile.

This is a great way to drive traffic to your business and generate sales. By utilising coupons you will be also able to measure the impact of using these posts on your profile.

COVID-19

Near the start of the pandemic, Google introduced a new type of post specifically for businesses to share their COVID-19 updates. Although less relevant for most businesses now, this is where you can include changes to your business hours, any new safety measures you have put in place, or even temporary closures. At the time this was a useful way for businesses to build trust with their customers and let them know which COVID-19 measures they had in place.

How to create a Google Profile Business Post

Creating a post is relatively straightforward, to create a Google Profile Business Post:

  1. Sign in to Google My Business.
  2. Choose the location you’d like to manage.
  3. Click Posts from the menu.
  4. In the top right, click Write a post.
  5. Choose the type of post you’d like to create.
  6. Enter the details of your post, then click Publish.

Why you should use posts to promote your business:

There are a few key reasons why you should use Google Profile Business Posts to promote your business:

  • Reach a wider audience: By creating a Google Business Profile and posting regularly, businesses can improve their visibility online and reach a wider audience. Google business profile posts appear in Google Search and Maps, so potential customers can easily find your business when they’re searching for products or services like yours.
  • Build trust and credibility: Posting regularly can help businesses build trust and credibility with potential customers. When customers see that you’re active on Google Business, they’ll know that you’re a business that is engaged with its customers and committed to providing the best possible experience.
  • Promote your products or services: Google Business is a great way to promote your products or services to potential customers. You can share announcements, offers, new or popular items in stock, or event details directly with your customers. Posting is a great way to connect with your customers, but moreover, you will be able to drive traffic whether that be virtual or real-world and drive sales.

Google business profile posts are a great way to promote your business and reach new customers. By creating informative and engaging posts, you can improve your visibility online, build trust and credibility with potential customers, generate interest in your products or services, as well as drive traffic to your business. seo.title: Digital marketing consultancy services explained
seo.description: We provide digital marketing consultancy services to small business owners who want to take their business to the next level. Find out more.

body.raw:
Author & Founder

Chris Talintyre

Digital Marketing Consultancy Service- Ignite your business success

In the UK, the current digital marketing service space is dominated by a small handful of digital ad agencies. Within the top 10 agencies, the average billing currently stands at £138m, which is over 12 times the turnover of all the other players in the industry (Source: Statista – “Digital marketing in the United Kingdom“).

But what if your company’s budgets are not big enough to attract one of the big 10 agencies? Or what do you do if you are just starting out and want to build your own competencies and knowledge? This is where a digital marketing consultancy can come in and grow your business.

What is digital marketing consultancy? In short, they are businesses or individuals that offer their expertise and knowledge in digital marketing to help client businesses. This can take many different forms, but the goal is always to help the client achieve their digital marketing goals.

A digital marketing consultancy will often have a wide range of services tailored for different digital marketing channels, allowing them to create bespoke digital marketing plans for their clients.

This is in contrast to an agency, which will often provide digital marketing services as part of a package or retainer agreement. The benefit of using digital marketing consultancy services is that you can get expert help and advice without having to commit to a long-term contract and have the flexibility to scale as and when your needs change.

Why digital marketing services are important for business growth

Digital marketing services can help your business achieve a number of goals. By working with a digital marketing consultancy, you could improve your website’s search engine ranking, develop social media audiences, deploy campaigns, increase traffic to your site, and improve your brand’s online reputation.

Digital marketing consultancies can also help you track your website’s analytics to ensure that you’re making the most of your digital marketing efforts.

If you’re not sure where to start with digital marketing, or if you want to ensure that your digital marketing campaigns are as effective as possible, digital marketing consultancy services can be a cost-effective approach for your business.

What services can you expect from a digital marketing consultancy?

There are a number of digital marketing services that digital marketing companies can provide. These services can be tailored to your specific needs, but some common digital marketing consultancy services include:

– Marketing Strategy Services – A digital marketing consultancy can help you develop a digital marketing strategy that meets your business goals. This can involve market research, target audience analysis, customer journey mapping, value proposition design, messaging hierarchy and the development of marketing objectives.

– Marketing Planning Services -Once you have a digital marketing strategy in place, they can help you develop a detailed plan to implement it. This can involve the development of detailed tactics, timelines and budgets.

– Implementation Services – Once your digital marketing plan is in place, they can help you with implementation services. This can involve website development, content creation, social media campaigns, lead generation campaigns, video production, digital advertising and more.

– Email marketing -Email marketing can be a great way to keep in touch with your customers and build relationships with potential leads. A digital marketing consultancy can help you create email campaigns that are targeted, engaging, and effective.

– Pay-per-click (PPC) advertising – PPC is a form of digital advertising where you pay to have your ad displayed on search engines and other websites. A consultancy can help you create and manage a PPC campaign that will reach your target audience and generate leads.

– Analytics – Tracking your website’s analytics is important to ensure that your digital marketing campaigns are effective. A consultancy can help you set up tracking and reporting so that you can measure your website’s traffic, conversion rates, and other key metrics.

– Conversion Rate Optimisation – Conversion rate optimisation (CRO) is the process of improving your website to increase the percentage of visitors who take the desired action, such as making a purchase or signing up for a newsletter. They can help you improve your website’s design, copy, and call-to-actions to increase conversions.

– Fractional Marketing Services – Most consultancies will be able to allow you to take a fraction of one of the service areas they provide. This could range from a fractional CMO or Marketing Director working on your business for a number of days a month to a specialist function such as SEO or PPC expert.

Digital marketing consultancy services can be a great way to improve your digital marketing efforts and grow your business. Some even offer mentoring and coaching as well, which is particularly helpful if do not have budget for their consultancy services. If you’re looking for expert help and advice, without having to commit to a long-term contract, digital marketing consultancy services could be the right solution for you.

How to find the best digital marketing consultancy for your needs

When looking for digital marketing consultancy services, there are a few things you should keep in mind.

First, make sure that the digital marketing company you’re working with is experienced and knowledgeable in the digital marketing services that you need.

Second, ask for referrals from other businesses or individuals who have previously used digital marketing consultancy services.

Finally, get a detailed proposal from them that outlines the scope of work and the cost of their services.

By following these tips and reading our full guide, you can be sure to find digital marketing consultancy services that will be valuable assets to your business.

Tips for getting the most out of digital marketing consultancy

When working with a digital marketing consultancy, there are a number of things you can do to ensure that the relationship is effective.

First, be clear about your goals and objectives for speaking to them. Be prepared to outline why you are considering this route and lay out any business challenges you have. This will allow them to tailor a proposal for your needs rather than a cookie-cutter approach based on what most businesses ask for.

Second, provide them with all the information and resources they need to be successful. Including consumer research that you have, past results from campaigns and a copy of your business plan.

Finally, be sure to stay involved throughout the digital marketing process so that you can provide feedback and make adjustments as needed. Often it is useful to start with a test campaign or a discovery project to see if you can build a mutually beneficial partnership.

By following these tips, you can be sure to get the most out of digital marketing consultancy services. If you’d like more information book a free call or take a look at this useful guide from DAN.

Conclusion

Digital marketing consultancy services can be a great way to improve your digital marketing efforts and grow your business. If you’re looking for expert help and advice, without having to commit to a long-term contract, digital marketing consultancy services could be the right solution for you.

About Polything

At Polything, we help companies use the power of storytelling to elevate their marketing and grow their business. Our collaborative and strategic approach to marketing can be applied to any direct-to-consumer business, and we work with clients all over the UK and further afield. Our team is experienced and passionate about helping businesses achieve their goals, and we’re always on the lookout for new and innovative ways to market products and services. If you’re interested get in touch to receive a strategic marketing plan example pdf, free of charge. So if you are looking for a digital marketing consultant London, please drop us a line.

Is your brand truly distinctive?

Many brands struggle to carve out a unique space in their market. Your brand’s unique value proposition should be a shining beacon, not a distant glimmer.

Our diagnostic tool measures how well your brand establishes a unique emotional connection maintains consistency across all touchpoints, and adapts to market changes—all the while staying true to its core identity.

Dare to find out the truth with our Distinctive Brand Index assessment. The results might surprise you!

Take the Assessment
What is a digital marketing consultancy service?

A digital marketing consultancy service is a professional service provided by experienced consultants or agencies that specialise in developing and implementing digital marketing strategies for businesses. These consultants offer expert guidance, analysis, and execution of various digital marketing techniques, including search engine optimisation (SEO), pay-per-click (PPC) advertising, social media marketing, email marketing, content marketing, and more.

Why should a business consider hiring a digital marketing consultancy service?

There are several compelling reasons for businesses to seek the assistance of a digital marketing consultancy service. Firstly, these consultants possess in-depth knowledge and expertise in the ever-evolving digital landscape, enabling them to develop effective strategies tailored to the client’s specific goals and target audience. Secondly, they have access to specialised tools and resources that can streamline the implementation and monitoring of digital marketing campaigns. Additionally, outsourcing digital marketing efforts to consultants allows businesses to focus on their core operations while leveraging the expertise of professionals in this field.

What services are typically offered by a digital marketing consultancy?

A comprehensive digital marketing consultancy service typically offers a wide range of services to cater to the diverse needs of businesses. These may include search engine optimisation (SEO) to improve website visibility and organic search rankings, pay-per-click (PPC) advertising management for targeted online advertising campaigns, social media marketing to establish and maintain a strong online presence, email marketing for effective lead nurturing and customer engagement, content marketing to create valuable and engaging content, website design and development, conversion rate optimisation to maximise conversions, and analytics and reporting to track and measure the success of digital marketing efforts.

How can a business choose the right digital marketing consultancy service?

When selecting a digital marketing consultancy service, businesses should consider several factors. Firstly, evaluate the consultancy’s experience, expertise, and track record in delivering successful digital marketing campaigns for clients in similar industries or niches. Secondly, assess their comprehensive understanding of various digital marketing channels and their ability to develop integrated strategies. Additionally, inquire about their approach to reporting and analytics, as well as their commitment to staying updated with the latest industry trends and best practices. It is also advisable to review client testimonials, case studies, and portfolios to gain insights into their work quality and client satisfaction.

What are the benefits of working with a digital marketing consultancy service?

Working with a digital marketing consultancy service offers numerous benefits to businesses. These consultants bring specialised knowledge, objective perspectives, and a data-driven approach to digital marketing strategies. They can help businesses stay ahead of the competition by leveraging the latest industry trends and technologies. Additionally, consultancies often have access to advanced tools and resources that may be costly for businesses to acquire independently. Furthermore, by outsourcing digital marketing efforts, businesses can focus their internal resources on core operations while benefiting from the expertise of seasoned professionals. Ultimately, a reputable digital marketing consultancy service can contribute to increased online visibility, lead generation, customer engagement, and overall business growth.

seo.title: How can mentoring help your business grow?
seo.description: Find out how mentoring can be a valuable tool that can help businesses grow by fostering the development of their employees.

body.raw:
Mentoring is a process in which a more experienced individual guides a less experienced person to achieve their goals. Within an organizational context, it is a valuable tool that can help businesses grow by fostering the development of their employees. In this article, we’ll explore what it is, how it differs from coaching, and the benefits it can bring to your business.

What is Mentoring?

Mentoring is a relationship between two individuals, where the mentor acts as a guide and counsellor, sharing their knowledge and experience to help the mentee achieve their goals. Julie Starr defines a mentor as “someone who takes on the role of a trusted advisor, supporter, teacher and wise counsel to another person. A mentor adopts a primarily selfless role in supporting the learning development and ultimate success of another person” (Starr 2021).

The mentor provides guidance, advice, and support, and helps the mentee build the skills and knowledge they need to succeed in their role. These relationships are typically long-term, with regular meetings over a period of several months or even years.

The difference between mentoring and coaching?

While coaching and mentoring share some similarities, they are different processes with different goals. CIPD defines coaching as aiming “to produce optimal performance and improvement at work. It focuses on specific skills and goals, although it may also have an impact on an individual’s personal attributes such as social interaction or confidence” (CIPD). Coaching is typically focused on helping an individual improve their performance in a specific area, such as communication or time management. The coach works with the individual to set goals and develop a plan to achieve them. Coaching is usually time-limited, with a defined end-point, and is focused on short-term goals and immediate results.

Mentoring, on the other hand, is more holistic and long-term. The mentor helps the mentee develop their skills and knowledge in a range of areas, and provides guidance and support as they grow and progress in their role. The mentor helps the mentee identify their strengths and weaknesses, and supports them as they work to overcome challenges and achieve their goals.

The importance of mentoring to your business

Mentors can bring a range of benefits to your business, including:

  • Improved employee development: It helps employees build the skills and knowledge they need to succeed in their role, which can lead to improved job performance and career progression.
  • Increased engagement and motivation: It helps employees feel valued and supported, which can increase their engagement and motivation levels.
  • Better retention: It helps employees build strong relationships with their colleagues, which can improve their sense of belonging and reduce the risk of turnover.
  • Improved succession planning: It can help you identify and develop future leaders within your organization, which can help you plan for succession and ensure a smooth transition of leadership.
  • Improved diversity and inclusion: it can help create a more inclusive workplace by providing opportunities for employees from diverse backgrounds to connect and grow.

Structure, Duration, and Expertise

When it comes to mentoring, the structure, duration, and expertise of the relationship can vary widely depending on the needs of the individuals involved. Some common structures for relationships include one-on-one meetings, group sessions, and email or phone correspondence. The duration of a relationship can range from several months to several years, depending on the goals of the individuals involved.

When it comes to expertise, the mentor should have relevant knowledge and experience in the area they are mentoring in. For example, if a mentee is looking to develop their leadership skills, they may seek out a mentor with experience in leadership and management. The mentor should also have strong interpersonal skills, be a good listener, and be able to provide constructive feedback.

A quote to ponder:

In conclusion, mentoring and coaching offer a wide range of benefits to individuals and organizations. Whether your goal is to improve employee engagement and productivity or to develop leadership skills, both mentoring and coaching can help you achieve your goals and drive business growth. If you’re interested in learning more about how mentoring programmes can help your business, don’t hesitate to reach out to us today.
